title: 普京：俄中关系将继续深化发展，取得新成就
translation:
Russian President Vladimir Putin stated on the 18th that Russia-China relations will continue to deepen and develop, achieve new achievements, and benefit the people of both countries.
In the early morning of the 18th local time, Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters, thanking voters for their support. When accepting questions from Xinhua News Agency reporters, he said that after years of development, Russia-China relations are very stable and highly complementary.
Putin pointed out that Russia and China have many points of convergence in economic, diplomatic and other fields. As far as the development of the Eurasian region is concerned, Russia-China relations are an important stabilizing factor, and the joint construction of the "Belt and Road" initiative proposed by China is very important.
Putin spoke positively of China's development achievements. He believes that China is achieving rapid development with great confidence and transforming into an innovative economy; China is increasingly active on the international stage and has achieved great success, and has many friends around the world.
Putin emphasized that Taiwan is an inalienable part of China; those attempts to provoke provocations around Taiwan and take various measures to delay China's development will undoubtedly fail completely.
According to data released by the Russian Central Election Commission in the early morning of the 18th local time, of the 85% of votes that have been counted in this presidential election, Putin led other candidates by a wide margin with 87.19% of the votes, and has actually won the presidential election.
Official voting for Russia’s eighth presidential election will be held from the 15th to the 17th. According to Russian presidential election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes is elected president. The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the final results of the presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within 3 days after the election results are confirmed.
input:
The development of bilateral relations between China and Russia.
Putin delivering a speech.
Putin thanking Russian voters in a speech.
Joint construction of the Belt and Road Initiative by China and Russia.
The Belt and Road Initiative proposed by China.
Promotion of national development by Vladimir Putin.
Transforming a country's economy.
Western attempts to create provocations.

title: 俄大选最后一天：“中午反普京”行动引爆全球-环球大观-万维读者网（电脑版）
translation:
At another polling station, another young woman who had similarly disguised her identity said she had voted for the "least suspicious" of the three candidates running against Putin.

People queue outside the Russian Embassy on the last day of the Russian presidential election. London, UK, March 17, 2024 REUTERS - Kevin Coombs
“Change happens when least expected”
A male student who voted in Moscow told Navalny's channel that people like him who disagree with the current system have to live regardless.
Because "history shows that change always happens when least expected," he said.
Reuters said the demonstrators constituted only a small portion of Russia's 114 million voters and that Mr Putin was poised to tighten his grip on power in an election that should deliver a landslide victory.
Russian Foreign Ministry spokesperson Maria Zakharova questioned the idea that those who voted at foreign embassies were Putin opponents and accused Western media of spreading propaganda about the incident.
The Kremlin views Navalny's political allies, most of whom are based outside Russia, as dangerous extremists who destabilize the country on behalf of the West. Putin enjoys overwhelming support among ordinary Russians, the report said, noting that polls show his approval rating exceeds 80 percent.
It is difficult to estimate how many people took part in the protests, as Russia is a vast country spanning 11 time zones and voters participating in the protests were dispersed.
Navalny's channel showed the number of people lining up at each polling station at noon today ranged from dozens to hundreds.
Some polling stations had thousands of people
Reuters reporters saw that at noon, the flow of voters, especially young people, increased slightly at some polling stations in Moscow and Yekaterinburg. There were hundreds of people queuing, and in some places there were even thousands of people.
Some said they were protesting, although there was little on the surface to distinguish them from ordinary voters.
Leonid Volkov, an aide to Navalny who was hammered in Lithuania last week, estimated that "hundreds of thousands" of people came to the polls (at noon) in Moscow, St. Petersburg, Yekaterinburg and other cities.
input:
People living.
Putin tightening his grip on power and control over Russian society and politics.
Russia spanning 11 time zones.
People lining up at polling stations in Russia.

In February 2022, Russia, under the leadership of Putin, did something that no state in the world has dared to do for a long time in modern international reality: it challenged American hegemony, a “world based on rules” arbitrarily invented in Washington and equally arbitrarily implemented by it (or not performed). title: Путин побеждает с 87,28 % голосов: как прошли самые скандальные выборы в истории России. Главные итоги выборов президента России 2024
translation:
What's the result?
The 2024 Russian presidential elections were a triumph for Vladimir Putin and at the same time revealed deep divisions in society. On the one hand, the incumbent president received record voter support and strengthened his power for a new term. On the other hand, the elections were accompanied by numerous violations, protests and criticism from the opposition and the West.

It is obvious that the legitimacy of these elections and the further stability of the existing system will largely depend on the ability of the authorities to ensure a real increase in the standard of living of the population, reduce social inequality and find new points of support in society. Otherwise, Putin’s record turnout and result may turn out to be a Pyrrhic victory, followed by an increase in protest sentiments and a deepening of the crisis in the country.

In the meantime, Russia is entering a new political cycle with a familiar leader and a set of problems. And the future of the country for years to come will depend on whether Putin and his team will be able to find adequate answers to these challenges. For now, all we can do is watch the developments and hope for the best. After all, as they say, “hope dies last.” Even in Russian politics.

title: 俄媒：普京以在线形式参加俄罗斯总统选举投票
translation:
Official voting for the eighth presidential election of the Russian Federation will be held from March 15 to 17. According to "Russia Today" (RT), on March 15, the Kremlin Palace announced that Russian President Vladimir Putin will participate in the Russian presidential election online.
Russian President Vladimir Putin took part in voting in Russia's presidential election online. Source: RT video screenshot

In addition, RT quoted RIA News Agency as saying that on March 15, Medvedev, Vice Chairman of the Russian Federation Security Council, went to the polling station to vote in the Russian presidential election.
According to media reports, polling stations in Kamchatka Krai, Chukotka Autonomous Region and other places located in the easternmost part of Russian territory opened at 8:00 local time on the 15th, and voting for the 2024 Russian presidential election officially began. Current Russian President Vladimir Putin, Slutsky from the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia, Kharitonov from the Communist Party of the Russian Federation and Davankov from the New People's Party of Russia will run for the next president.
According to the "Presidential Election Law of the Russian Federation", the president is the head of state of Russia and each term is 6 years. Any citizen of the Russian Federation who is over 35 years old, has lived in Russia for more than 25 years, and does not currently hold or have held the citizenship of any other country in the past can run for president. According to regulations, the counting of votes for the presidential election will begin after the polls close. The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the final results of the election no later than March 28 and announce them within three days after confirmation.
input: Confirmation and announcement of final election results by the Russian Central Election Commission.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·选民｜年轻的俄罗斯人怎么想？
translation:
Russia will hold a presidential election on March 15-17, 2024. The 71-year-old current President Putin seeks to serve as head of state for the fifth time. This election is Russia’s first presidential election since the adoption of constitutional amendments in 2020, and it is also Russia’s first wartime election.
The All-Russian Public Opinion Research Center announced the latest poll results on March 4. Among 1,600 Russian citizens over the age of 18 who were polled through telephone interviews, 70% of the respondents said they would definitely participate in the vote. Voters who plan to vote 75% of people said they would support Putin in the general election. Subsequently, estimates released by the center on March 11 based on a telephone survey showed that Putin may receive 82% of the vote.
In February 2022, Putin took "special military action." Now that the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has lasted for more than two years, the lives of Russians during wartime have undergone tremendous changes. Despite Western sanctions, the Russian economy is expected to grow by 2.6% this year, according to the International Monetary Fund. At the same time, Russia's inflation rate will exceed 7%, but the unemployment rate remains low; last October, Russia's unemployment rate fell below 3% (2.9%) for the first time since the collapse of the Soviet Union.
During the election campaign, Putin repeatedly focused on people's livelihood issues, promising to provide cheap mortgage loans with government subsidies to help young families, especially families with children; in addition, he also promised to provide support in health care, education, science, culture and sports. to invest more government funds in areas while continuing efforts to eradicate poverty.
What do young Russians think about the conflict, elections and the future? The Paper (www.thepaper.cn) chatted with them.
"He gave people in Luhansk a better life"

title: Итоги выборов президента: Победа Путина, второе место КПРФ, рекордная явка
translation:
Following the results of the last elections, Vladimir Putin was re-elected President of Russia for six years. Based on the results of processing 100% of the PEC protocols, the current head of state was supported by 87.28% of citizens. Turnout broke a record, exceeding 77%. The candidate from the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, Nikolai Kharitonov, came in second place with 4.31%. At the same time, for the first time in post-Soviet history, the Communists received less than 10%.

By 15:00 on Monday, 100% of the final protocols of precinct election commissions had been processed. The vote count is complete. According to the information board on the CEC website, the places were distributed as follows:

Vladimir Putin (self-nomination) - 87.28%
Nikolai Kharitonov (Communist Party of the Russian Federation) - 4.31%
Vladislav Davankov (“New People”) - 3.85%
Leonid Slutsky (LDPR) - 3.20%
Thus, current President Vladimir Putin was re-elected to a new six-year term of office (the current term expires on May 7, 2024). Let us remind you that he ran as a self-nominated candidate and with the support of two parliamentary parties - United Russia and A Just Russia.
input:
The announcement of election results.
Vladimir Putin received approximately 87% of the votes in the Russian presidential election according to the Central Election Commission.
Processing of election protocols in Russia.

title: ЦИК объявил о победе Путина с 87% голосов
translation:
MOSCOW, March 17 (Reuters) - Current Russian President Vladimir Putin wins the presidential election with 87.17% of the votes based on the results of processing 80.93% of the protocols, data from the Central Election Commission shows.

The turnout in the elections was 74.22% percent.

In second place is the candidate from the Communist Party of the Russian Federation Nikolai Kharitonov with 4.22% of the votes, in third is Vladislav Davankov from “New People” with 4.03%, in fourth is Leonid Slutsky from the Liberal Democratic Party with 3.16%.

Polls predicted an unconditional victory for Putin in his fifth election.

In power for almost a quarter of a century, Putin promises in the next six years to reduce poverty, increase life expectancy, increase non-resource exports, increase labor productivity and ensure growth in investment.

In March, he estimated his initiatives for the next six years at 14 trillion rubles.
input:
Vladimir Putin received approximately 87% of the votes in the Russian presidential election according to the Central Election Commission.
Processing of election protocols in Russia.
Reducing poverty in Russia.
Increase in Russia's non-resource and non-energy exports.

title: 华语智库:为什么普京能高票胜选连任俄总统？当天他给我国送来“超级大礼”！
translation:
The fourth is to focus on improving national defense strength and building a strong defense barrier.

After Russia became independent, it took over most of the military power of the former Soviet Union. However, due to the long time difference and the economic lag at the beginning of Russia's independence, some establishment systems, weapons and equipment cannot keep up with the needs of modern warfare.

As the supreme commander of the Russian armed forces, Putin focuses on the improvement of combat performance, focuses on military reform and development, timely rationalizes the internal command system of the army, adjusts the balance of strategic and conventional forces, transforms and updates old weapons and equipment, and enhances various Collaborative combat capabilities among the troops, increased investment in actual combat training of the troops, timely released the Russian military equipment development outline for 2018-2028, and proposed the application of drone smart weapons, hypersonic weapons, and digital command systems. Make your requirements clear and work hard to implement them. In 2012, the proportion of modern weapons and equipment in the Russian army was only 16%. By the end of 2021, this proportion reached 71.2%, and now the proportion of modern weapons and equipment has increased to 95%.

In particular, Russia has been successfully developing high-end, sophisticated and cutting-edge weapons in recent years. The testing of the "Haiyan" nuclear-powered strategic cruise missile, which is said to have unlimited range, and the "Poseidon" nuclear-powered unmanned submarine are about to be completed. "Sarmat" heavy intercontinental ballistic missile has been delivered to the troops. "Avangard" hypersonic intercontinental missiles and "Peresvet" laser weapons are on combat readiness duty. The "Dagger" hypersonic missile system and the "Zircon" sea-based hypersonic strike system have been put into use. Putin once said proudly that "these weapons have unique characteristics."

In addition, Russia, which has more than 5,900 nuclear warheads, currently has some strategic nuclear forces in a state of full readiness, and its national security capabilities have been significantly improved, creating an effective strategic deterrent to the United States and NATO. For more than 20 years, no matter what Russia's strategic measures and combat operations are, the United States and Western countries have not dared to act rashly against Russia.

title: 俄大选最后一天：“中午反普京”行动引爆全球-环球大观-万维读者网（电脑版）
translation:
The 71-year-old Putin first became the president of Russia in 1999. If he can complete his new presidential term in the next six years, his reign will not only surpass Stalin, the dictator of the Soviet Union, but also become the longest ruler of Russia in the past 200 years. The longest leader.
According to the latest report from Agence France-Presse on Sunday, many people lined up in long lines outside some polling stations in Moscow at noon on Sunday in response to calls for protests. Russian authorities have arrested at least 74 Russians protesting against the electoral vote in more than a dozen cities.
At the time of this election, Putin's unprovoked large-scale aggressive war against neighboring Ukraine in the name of "special military operations" has just entered its third year. This is the largest war with the deadliest casualties in Europe since World War II.
Reuters reported on Sunday that in the three days as Russians went to the polls, fierce confrontations between the Russian and Ukrainian armies also followed.
Russia said on Sunday that Ukraine had launched 35 drone attacks across a wide range of Russia, including Moscow, causing a fire at an oil refinery and cutting power to other areas.
The governor of Russia's Samara region said on Saturday that two local oil refineries were attacked by Ukrainian drones and caused fires, but there were no casualties.
On the same day, the governor of Russia's Belgorod region also stated that the city of Belgorod, the state capital, was shelled by Ukrainian troops that day, killing two people and injuring three others. The governor also posted on social media that due to the increase in attacks from Ukraine, the state government has decided that local shopping malls will be closed on Sunday and Monday, and schools will also be closed on Monday and Tuesday.
According to a report from the Russian Satellite News Agency, Kremlin spokesman Dmitri Peskov told reporters that Ukrainian "saboteurs" made several attempts to invade Russia's Belgorod and Kursk regions early Saturday morning. territory, but 1,700 of the 2,500 "saboteurs" suffered losses, including 550 killed.
input:
Putin surpassing Stalin as Russia's longest-serving leader.

title: 胜选后,普京最新表态
translation:
According to CCTV News Client, the latest preliminary vote count data for the presidential election released by the Russian Central Election Commission shows that 95% of the votes have been counted so far; among the four candidates, current President Putin leads by a wide margin with 87.32% of the votes. has actually won this presidential election.
In the early morning of the 18th local time, Russian President Vladimir Putin held a press conference to thank voters for their trust and support. He will continue to promote national development in his new term.
On the same day, when talking about the Taiwan issue, Putin said that "there is no doubt that Taiwan is an inalienable part of the People's Republic of China." He also said that attempts by "unfriendly people" towards China to use Taiwan to create provocations and impose sanctions are destined to fail completely.
When talking about China-Russia relations, he said that Russia-China relations are a stabilizing factor in international relations.
"The relationship between our two countries has gradually taken shape over the past 20 years. The relationship between the two countries is strong and complementary. I believe that this relationship will continue to be maintained." Putin said, "The most important thing is that our national interests are consistent. "This creates a favorable environment for solving our common tasks and in the field of international relations, where relations between Russia and China are a stabilizing factor."
In addition, when it comes to foreign affairs, Putin said that Russia is ready and willing to peacefully resolve the Russian-Ukrainian conflict through negotiations, but the premise is that Kyiv hopes to establish friendly and good-neighborly relations with Russia, rather than gaining time to rearm the severely damaged Ukrainian army.
The Russian Satellite News Agency mentioned that when asked whether a full-scale conflict was possible between Russia and NATO, Putin replied that he believed "everything is possible" in today's world.
The official voting for the eighth presidential election of the Russian Federation will be held from the 15th to the 17th. The Russian Central Election Commission stated that as of 18:00 local time on the 17th, 74.4% of voters across Russia had participated in the voting. The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the results of the presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within three days after the election results are confirmed.

Western attempts to create provocations.

title: 普京无悬念胜选 演说提与习近平友谊 | 德国之声 来自德国 介绍德国 | DW | 18.03.2024
translation:
Russian opposition leader Navalny died in prison in February this year. His widow, Yulia Navalnaya, appeared at the Russian Embassy in Berlin on the 17th to cast her vote overseas. Many people at the scene chanted her name to express support. Yulia said she also wrote Navalny's name on the ballot.
According to Reuters, hundreds or even thousands of people lined up in Moscow, Yekaterinburg and other places, but it is difficult to confirm whether they were all for protest or whether this reflected high turnout. The Kremlin claimed that the voting showed the Russian people's trust in Putin and their support for "special military operations in Ukraine."
During the election, the opposition camp launched a series of protests. Several news agencies reported on Friday that dye was poured into ballot boxes or set on fire at polling stations. According to the human rights monitoring group OVD-Info, at least 80 people were arrested across Russia on the 18th due to protests. A woman was arrested by police in Yekaterinburg on Saturday as she poured green dye into a ballot box. There have been many incidents in Russia in the past where opposition figures, including Navalny, were doused with green dye.
Russia is the largest country in the world, spanning 11 time zones from the Kamchatka Peninsula in the east to the exclave of Kaliningrad in the west, so the entire election event lasts for three days.
The Russian government warned of the protests, saying it could see "green shoots of extremism." Screenshots published by the independent news platform Meduza showed that some dissidents in the capital Moscow received threatening text messages with the following content: "Whether you support extremist organizations or not, you are welcome to participate in the voting activities in Moscow, but when voting, please remain calm , don’t stand in long lines or make other provocations.” It’s unclear who sent the messages.
input:
The death of opposition leader Alexei Navalny in an Arctic prison.
Casting rigged ballots in a Russian election.
Chanting names and slogans at political events.
People lining up at polling stations in Russia.
Arrests of individuals across Russia during protests, monitored by OVD-Info.
Russia spanning 11 time zones.
Russian authorities' warnings against demonstrations and unsanctioned activities.
Western attempts to create provocations.

title: 习近平祝贺普京“连任”   中俄联手引发国际安全担忧 — 普通话主页
translation:
Russian President Vladimir Putin was successfully re-elected in the general election held over the weekend, and his "old friend" Xi Jinping also immediately sent a congratulatory message. It is generally believed that Putin and Xi Jinping, who has been reelected for three consecutive terms, will further strengthen the Sino-Russian alliance. What impact will the combination of "authoritarianism" and "totalitarianism" have on the international security situation?
The Russian presidential election, which has attracted worldwide attention, has come to an end. According to the vote counting results released by the Russian Central Election Commission on March 18, local time, current President Vladimir Putin won the fifth term with 87.19% of the vote. His 24-year rule over the Russian Federation will be "continued" "6 years.
The international community criticized Putin for his re-election; Xi Jinping immediately sent a congratulatory message
The Russia-Ukraine war is still in a stalemate three years ago, and Putin's re-election immediately attracted criticism and dissatisfaction from the international community. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said in a video on social media platform It was also pointed out that the Russian presidential election does not have "legitimacy".
However, Chinese leader Xi Jinping immediately called Putin to congratulate him on his re-election as President of the Russian Federation. Xi Jinping said in his congratulatory message: "Your re-election fully reflects the support of the Russian people for you. I believe that under your leadership, Russia will be able to achieve greater achievements in national development and construction." According to Russian media "Russia Today" (RT ) reported that North Korea’s supreme leader Kim Jong-un also sent a congratulatory message to Putin.
At a regular press conference held by the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Monday, the new spokesperson Lin Jian congratulated Putin on his re-election. He said: "We are convinced that under the strategic guidance of President Xi Jinping and President Putin, China-Russia relations will continue to move forward."
Wang Weizheng, dean of the College of Arts and Sciences and professor of political science at Adelphi University in the United States, told this station: "(Putin's re-election) makes Chinese President Xi Jinping feel like they are united for warmth, because both of them are outside the Western camp. Russia had already attacked Ukraine before It has been said that the relationship between the two countries has 'no upper limit', and it is very likely that the two countries will become the so-called axis powers."


On March 18, 2024, Putin delivered a speech at the Moscow campaign headquarters after the Russian presidential election. (Associated Press)








Last month, China confirmed that Putin will visit China again this year. This will be Putin's 19th visit to China since taking power in Russia.
input:
Western criticism of the Russian election.
Xi Jinping called Putin to congratulate him on his re-election as President of Russia.
China congratulating Putin on his re-election.
Promotion of national development by Vladimir Putin.
Conviction that China-Russia relations will strengthen under the guidance of President Xi Jinping and President Putin.
Russia's progression and strengthening.
Putin delivering a speech.

A young man named Ilya said: "I hope the situation will get better, but if a new person is elected, he may not be able to bear the heavy responsibilities of the government. An experienced person like Putin can make the country even in the current situation." Development can be achieved even in difficult situations. "Of course I support our President Putin," Moscow citizen Yevgeny said frankly after the vote. Regarding the future, the young man expressed his hope that the Russian economy will develop better and better and the national life will become more prosperous. 
Muraviev, an associate professor at Australia's Curtin University, said that Putin's massive support is "predictable" and that he is Russia's "crisis manager." "Russians are not willing to see anything happen to (the leader) while the war is going on. change".
Russia’s stance against NATO remains unchanged
Analysis points out that in terms of politics, last year Putin quelled the mutiny crisis of Prigozhin, the leader of the "Wagner" group, strengthened social control through legislation and other means, and basically maintained national security and social stability; in terms of military, he withstood the After the Ukrainian army's counteroffensive since the second half of last year, and with the recent slowdown in U.S. and European support for Kiev, the Russian army currently has the upper hand on the battlefield; in the economic field, the Russian economy has shown strong resilience and withstood the crazy sanctions of the West. , GDP growth last year was 3.6%, higher than the global average of 3%.
There is little doubt that Putin will win the election, and the military confrontation between Russia and NATO is expected to continue. Miron, a researcher at the Department of War Studies at King's College London, said Putin will continue his current policies domestically and internationally. Regarding the war in Ukraine, Miron said that from a military perspective, although there may be some adjustments to the roles of specific departments of the Russian military, especially the Black Sea Fleet, there are no signs of any change in the overall strategy. The Russian army may adopt a gradual approach to territorial expansion, especially in northern areas such as Kharkiv and southern areas such as Odessa.
After the death of Russian imprisoned opposition leader Navalny on February 16, his supporters asked voters who opposed Putin to go to the polling stations at noon on the 17th to vote, including casting an invalid vote, writing "Navalny" on the ballot, or putting "Navalny" on the ballot. vote for one of the other three candidates to lower Putin's vote share. The Kremlin has previously said that any action called by Navalny's allies would be considered a provocation, stressing that any illegal behavior would be clamped down by the police.

A total of four candidates participated in the election, including the current Russian President Vladimir Putin, the Russian Liberal Democratic Party's Slutsky, the Russian Federation's Communist Party Kharitonov and the Russian newcomer Davankov of the party.
According to data from the Russian Central Election Commission, among the 85% of votes counted in the Russian presidential election, Putin, Kharitonov, Davankov, and Slutsky received 87.19%, 4.24%, 3.99%, and 3.16% of the votes respectively. .
According to Russian presidential election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes in the election is elected president, so Putin has actually won the election. The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the results of the presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within 3 days after the election results are confirmed.
In the early morning of the 18th, Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters, thanking all voters for their support. He said that Russia will move forward further and become more solid, stronger and more efficient.
Technical independence, economic diversification
After the Russian economy suffered shocks in the early stages of the escalation of the Ukraine crisis, it has gradually shown resilience. Data released by the Russian Federal State Statistics Service in early February this year show that Russia’s GDP will grow by 3.6% in 2023. However, Western countries' blockade of Russia in the fields of finance, investment, and technological product imports has brought difficulties to the long-term development of the Russian economy. How to continue to hedge against the impact of Western sanctions is a task for Putin's administration.
In his State of the Nation Address delivered to both houses of parliament at the end of February, Putin stated that factors such as a lack of talent and insufficient own advanced technology may lead to a slowdown in economic growth. Therefore, the country will vigorously strengthen the development of education, science and technology and other fields, and let technological independence become the driving force for industrial upgrading to improve the efficiency and competitiveness of the Russian economy.
He proposed that by 2030, the share of Russia's high-tech products and services in the domestic market should increase by 50%, and the export of non-raw materials and non-energy products should increase by at least two-thirds. Russia should possess key technologies in fields involving citizens' health and food security, and achieve technological independence in fields that can promote sustainable economic development, such as machine tools, robots, transportation, unmanned driving, aviation, oceans, digital economy, new materials and chemistry. , investment in key areas should increase by 70%, and at least 100 more science and technology parks should be built.
Putin said that non-resource industries currently account for more than 90% of Russia's economic growth structure, and the Russian economy is becoming more diversified and sustainable.
Aksakov, chairman of the Financial Markets Committee of the Russian State Duma (lower house of parliament), said that the Russian economy is gradually adapting to Western sanctions and is changing rapidly. Western oppression has prompted Russia to vigorously promote the internal restructuring of its economy and speed up its transition away from resource dependence.
continuation of foreign policy
Russian experts believe that resisting Western containment and suppression, uniting friendly countries, and achieving established diplomatic goals will become the focus of Putin's future foreign policy.
Putin has said that no matter who wins the U.S. presidential election in 2024, the U.S. foreign policy toward Russia is unlikely to undergo fundamental changes, and the U.S. will still regard Russia as an enemy.
Mukhin, director of the Russian Political Information Center, said that Putin will continue to take a tough stance against unfriendly countries. Kortunov, an expert at the Russian Council for International Affairs, said that in the coming period, Russia and the United States will continue to have in-depth confrontation, but both sides will still maintain a certain degree of restraint to avoid accidents such as nuclear war.
Russian experts believe that Putin will continue his previous foreign policy, actively develop relations with friendly countries in Asia, Africa, the Middle East and Latin America, expand his circle of friends, strengthen his influence in international and regional organizations, and promote world multipolarity.
In addition, some analysts believe that Putin will pay more attention to the relationship between Russia and other BRICS countries in the future and expand this relationship to multiple areas including trade. Mukhin believes that Russia will continue to play an important role within frameworks such as the BRICS cooperation mechanism and the Shanghai Cooperation Organization.

title: 普京大选“获胜”虽无悬念，最后投票日见“中午反普京”人潮
translation:
The three-day voting in Russia's general election entered the final day on Sunday (March 17). After eliminating dissidents and suppressing dissent, the current President Vladimir Putin has secured an overwhelming "victory" even without counting the votes. But the opposition, which is banned from running in the election, is still calling on people to go to the polls at noon on the last day of voting to express symbolic protests.

The 71-year-old Putin first became the president of Russia in 1999. If he can complete his new presidential term in the next six years, his reign will not only surpass Stalin, the dictator of the Soviet Union, but also become the longest ruler of Russia in the past 200 years. The longest leader.
According to the latest report from Agence France-Presse on Sunday, many people lined up in long lines outside some polling stations in Moscow at noon on Sunday in response to calls for protests. Russian authorities have arrested at least 74 Russians protesting against the electoral vote in more than a dozen cities. 

At the time of this election, Putin's unprovoked large-scale aggressive war against neighboring Ukraine in the name of "special military operations" has just entered its third year. This is the largest war with the deadliest casualties in Europe since World War II.

Reuters reported on Sunday that in the three days as Russians went to the polls, fierce confrontations between the Russian and Ukrainian armies also followed.

Russia said on Sunday that Ukraine had launched 35 drone attacks across a wide range of Russia, including Moscow, causing a fire at an oil refinery and cutting power to other areas.

The governor of Russia's Samara region said on Saturday that two local oil refineries were attacked by Ukrainian drones and caused fires, but there were no casualties.

On the same day, the governor of Russia's Belgorod region also stated that the city of Belgorod, the state capital, was shelled by Ukrainian troops that day, killing two people and injuring three others. The governor also posted on social media that due to the increase in attacks from Ukraine, the state government has decided that local shopping malls will be closed on Sunday and Monday, and schools will also be closed on Monday and Tuesday.

title: «Угроза для Европы и мира». Что пишут зарубежные СМИ о победе Путина на выборах
translation:
Putin intends to use his new six-year term to further tighten his grip on Russian politics and continue military action in Ukraine. If he remains in power until the end of this term, his reign will be the longest since Catherine the Great.

The publication calls the past elections “the least transparent” in the modern history of Russia, since the work of independent observers “has been reduced to a level not seen since the collapse of the Soviet Union.”

According to the NYT editors, the Kremlin views these elections "as a ritual crucial to Putin's vision of himself as a truly people's leader." Analysts expect the Russian president will now promote military activists within the government, betting that Western support for Ukraine will eventually crumble and Kyiv will be forced to negotiate peace on Russia's terms.

Political analysts say the Russian leader needs to be seen as a big winner if he wants to have "free rein" in reviving Russia's conservative Orthodox traditions and ultimately prevail over Ukraine and the broader confrontation with the West, the newspaper writes. The WSJ predicts that the focus of Putin's fifth term will be on military action in Ukraine and securing Russian support for it.
input: Putin tightening his grip on power and control over Russian society and politics.

title: 俄罗斯大选 普京获胜几无悬念 | 俄大选 | 大纪元
translation:
On Friday (March 15), voters in 11 time zones across Russia went to vote, kicking off the three-day Russian general election. The outside world generally believes that there is little doubt that Russian President Putin will win re-election. This election will "give" Putin another six years of power.
Voters from some of Russia's more than 190 ethnic groups went to the polls, from Chukotka on the Pacific Ocean, 6,300 kilometers (3,900 miles) from Moscow, to the Baltic enclave of Kaliningrad on the border with Poland.
Although Putin launched Europe's deadliest war since World War II in 2022, the Russian president still dominates Russia's political landscape. None of the other three candidates on the ballot in Russia's general election, which begins on Friday, poses any credible challenge to Putin. The three candidates are Vladislav Davankov of the New People party, Leonid Slutsky of the Liberal Democratic Party (LDPR) and Communist candidate Nikolay Kharitonov.
These rivals are known as “institutional opposition.” They are seen as symbolic rivals and their parties generally support Putin's government. CNBC said the purpose of including them on the ballot was to bring a level of respectability to the vote and provide a semblance of pluralism to Russia's de facto authoritarian political system.
Putin is expected to easily win a fifth term, which will keep him in power in Russia until at least 2030.
The Kremlin says Putin will win because he will win widespread support to rescue Russia from post-Soviet chaos and stand up to an arrogant, hostile West.
Putin has been president or prime minister of Russia since late 1999. So far, he has shown no sign of relinquishing control of Russia. He has the support of a loyal inner circle and Russia's security services.
The shadow of the war in Ukraine hangs over this Russian election: Russia still has more than 1 million armed personnel engaged in fierce fighting on Ukraine's 1,000 kilometers (600 miles) front line.
Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu and Chief of General Staff Valery Gerasimov, who are responsible for directing Russia's war efforts, voted in Russia's Southern Military District.
More than 114 million Russians are eligible to vote, including voters in what Russia claims are "new territories." In October 2022, Russia announced the annexation of four Ukrainian regions. Ukraine says the Russian elections held there are illegal and invalid.
Ukraine's Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a statement on Thursday (March 14) that Russia's attempts to "imitate" the presidential election on its territory showed that "the Russian Federation continues to blatantly ignore the norms and principles of international law." The foreign ministry said voting in Ukrainian territories occupied by Russia was illegal and urged citizens in those areas not to vote.
Analysts pointed out that the Kremlin hopes to see high turnout in this election and hopes for a major victory for Putin to legitimize the war.
Andreas Tursa, Central and Eastern Europe consultant at consulting firm Teneo, commented on Thursday: "The Kremlin seeks an election result that will show public overwhelming support for Putin and his domestic and foreign policy agenda. sexual support.”
He added: "The Kremlin is using this election to reaffirm Putin's legitimacy, mobilize public support for his policies and demonstrate unity and resolve to external opponents." The Kremlin seeks a "landslide victory."
Russian opposition activists condemned the election. Most of them fled overseas to avoid arrest, imprisonment or assault. Yulia Navalnaya, the widow of late opposition leader Alexei Navalny, asked Russian voters to vote for "any candidate other than Putin" and called on Citizens voted collectively at noon local time on March 17 in an attempt to overwhelm the polling stations.
She also called on the West not to recognize the election results. Kremlin opponents have also called on supporters abroad to protest outside the Russian embassy this Sunday.

title: Итоги выборов-2024: Путин побеждает с рекордными результатом и явкой в истории РФ
translation:
The final voter turnout, taking into account remote electronic voting, which operated in a third of the regions, according to preliminary data, amounted to 74.22%, the CEC announced. This figure is likely to increase further.

The results are close to the figures that the media wrote on the eve of the elections. The turnout turned out to be the highest in the history of presidential elections in Russia.

In 2018, 67.54% of voters voted - this level was surpassed in the current elections a few hours before the polls closed on Sunday. True, six years ago the elections lasted only one day.

According to the Central Election Commission, people actively voted even in the regions bordering Ukraine, where shelling continued throughout the three election days. For example, in the Belgorod region the turnout in the middle of the day on Sunday, according to Russian authorities, exceeded 83%.

Russian authorities claim that in all new territories of the Russian Federation, Putin’s results were higher than the national average: in Zaporozhye, Donetsk and Lugansk regions - more than 90%, in the Kherson region - more than 88%.

It is worth noting that during the elections, violations were recorded, as well as attempts at acts of vandalism, which were suppressed by law enforcement officials. Some voters deliberately damaged ballot papers and wrote various inscriptions on them.

So in St. Petersburg, a protocol was drawn up against a voter to discredit the army for writing “No to war” on the ballot. In Kostroma, a protocol under the same article was drawn up against the secretary of the Kostroma branch of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, Andrei Tarasov. He posted a photo of a ballot with the words “No to war” and Vladimir Putin’s name crossed out.

The police detained people at polling stations on election days not only for protest inscriptions on ballots. The 2024 vote was unprecedented in the number of incidents of arson and damage to ballots.

Such vandalism affected areas throughout the country - in Moscow, St. Petersburg, Yekaterinburg, Voronezh, Rostov region, Krasnodar region and other regions.

Security forces are opening criminal cases under Article 141 of the Criminal Code - “obstruction of the exercise of electoral rights or the work of election commissions.” The maximum penalty for it is 5 years in prison.

In addition, about 280 thousand hacker attacks were blocked on remote electronic voting resources, said CEC Chairman Ella Pamfilova. But in general, according to the chairman of the Central Election Commission, there were no serious violations in the elections. “We are woolly, we are sitting, there is mostly garbage there, sucked out of thin air, there is nothing serious, so there is nothing to sort out now,” she said on March 16.

Despite all this, the violators failed to disrupt the election process and it ended successfully. Some state leaders have already rushed to congratulate Putin on his victory in the elections.

The first telegram on the occasion of the victory in the elections came to Russia from Tajikistan. The head of Tajikistan, Emomali Rahmon, congratulated Vladimir Putin on his victory even before the official end of the vote count.

title: 被建议新任期海外首访去中国，普京：一定会考虑
translation:
(Observer Network News) According to a report by Russia's TASS news agency on the 19th, late on Tuesday local time, Russian President Vladimir Putin said that he would consider choosing China as the destination for his first foreign visit after the start of his new presidential term.


According to reports, during a meeting with the leaders of various parties in the Russian State Duma that day, Putin was suggested to visit Beijing for the first time after the start of his new term. He smiled and said that he would "definitely consider it, no joke."


Reuters reported on the 20th, citing five anonymous sources, that Putin may plan to visit China in May this year. The Kremlin responded by saying that specific information about Putin's overseas trip will be released as the trip approaches.





On March 17, after the voting in the Russian presidential election, Putin held a press conference to thank voters for their trust and support. Picture from The Paper


On March 17, local time, the Russian presidential election came to an end. According to preliminary statistics, current President Putin won the election and was re-elected with a vote rate of more than 87%, significantly leading other candidates.


According to Reuters, the presidential inauguration will be held around May 7, and Putin’s first overseas trip during his new presidential term will also be on the agenda. Some foreign diplomats and observers said they expected Putin's first stop after his re-election would be China.


According to the report, five sources said to be familiar with the situation revealed that Putin will go to Beijing to hold talks with Chinese leaders in May this year. One of them said that the trip to China may start in late May.


Russian Presidential Press Secretary Peskov responded, "We are currently preparing for several presidential visits and high-level contacts. We will inform everyone as (the event) approaches."


TASS reported that at the Russian State Duma party leaders’ meeting held on Tuesday local time, Zyuganov, chairman of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, proposed to Putin that Beijing should be his first choice for overseas visits. "I hope your first visit will be to the East, not the West." TASS quoted him as saying.


Putin reportedly responded to him with a smile: "I will definitely consider what you just said, no joke."


Reuters pointed out that Russia and China have recently had close relations. Putin's most recent visit to China was in October last year when he was invited to attend the third "Belt and Road" International Cooperation Summit Forum hosted by China. This is Putin's first visit to a major global power since the outbreak of the Russia-Ukraine conflict, which has aroused intense attention from the outside world.

The approaching date of Putin's overseas trip.
Putin thanking Russian voters in a speech.

title: Выборы президента России. Главное
translation:
What will happen after the elections
The inauguration of the elected president should take place on May 7 (six years from the date of the inauguration of the president who won the previous election). The government will resign on the same day. In 2018, Putin nominated Dmitry Medvedev for the post of head of government on the day of his inauguration. The State Duma confirmed him as prime minister the next day, May 8. Medvedev presented the composition of the cabinet of ministers to the president ten days later, on May 18.

After the reform of the Constitution, the Prime Minister will nominate the majority of ministers to the State Duma. The President will propose candidates for the posts of heads of the special services, the Ministry of Internal Affairs, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Defense, having consulted on them with the Federation Council.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·议题｜参军、跳槽、养娃……“我们在同一条船上”
translation:
In comparison, according to data from the Russian State Statistics Service in September 2023, the average monthly salary in Russia is 70,900 rubles (approximately RMB 5,587).
After the Russian-Ukrainian conflict broke out, Sasha, a contract soldier, was immediately sent to the front line of the conflict. For two years, Sasha rarely had a vacation, was separated from his family for long periods of time, and is still fighting on the front lines.
As the conflict drags on, the treatment of frontline soldiers has become a matter of concern to all walks of life in Russia. In February 2023, Putin stated in his State of the Union address that considering that participants in special military operations face tremendous physical and psychological pressure and face risks to their health and life every day, they should be provided with medical assistance at least once every six months and every day. A regular leave of at least 14 days so that each soldier has the opportunity to visit relatives and friends.
In June of that year, Putin signed an order to distribute free land to participants of special military operations who were awarded the title of "Hero of Russia" and other medals, as well as veterans who participated in the operations. The order does not apply to Moscow, St. Petersburg and Sevastopol in the Crimea region, but Putin requested other social support packages there.
In February 2024, Putin once again emphasized in his State of the Union address on the eve of the Russian presidential election that Russia's future will largely depend on the courage and determination of soldiers participating in special military operations. They should serve in education, business and state administration. Holding a leadership position will give priority to higher education and professional education at first-class universities, and priority for promotion in the Russian Armed Forces.
Whenever he talks about war, Andre's feelings are always very complicated and contradictory. He admitted that some people voluntarily went to the front line, some of them for generous rewards. But in his opinion, people will not go to the front line where the shadow of death is looming just because of money.
As for his friends, Andre said reluctantly that he had no choice, but he also knew his mission.
Compared to Sasha, who has been fighting on the front line, Andre's other friend Ilya seems to be luckier. A few years ago, Ilya entered the army to perform compulsory military service after completing 11th grade courses. Ilya is an excellent boxer. Due to his good physical fitness and good treatment in the army, Ilya became a contract soldier after completing his compulsory military service.
Before February 2022, Ilya left the army after his contract expired and was therefore not sent to the front line, while one of his comrades had just extended his contract a few months before the war. Unfortunately, Ilya's comrade died on the front line from a shrapnel that penetrated his stomach. He was only 25 years old when he died.
"Ilya went to the funeral of his comrade and he was very sad. The war was terrible, people were dying on both sides... I certainly hope that the authorities can solve the problem through negotiations without going to war, but I can also understand Why Putin does this is because he has no choice," Andrei said.

translation:
In the Russian general election held from 15 to 17 days in 2024, according to the latest information released on the Russian Central Election Commission website on March 18, local time, all votes have been counted. Preliminary data shows that current President Putin received 76,277,708 votes. The vote rate was 87.28%.
“Russia is finally becoming more like Russia”
During the last presidential election in 2018, the so-called "Crimea effect" of 2014 had long since disappeared, and the election did not cause any ripples in the village. But this year things are completely different. In addition to general election posters calling on everyone to vote, elements related to "special military operations" can be seen everywhere: St. George ribbons (a ribbon created by Russia to commemorate the victory in the Great Patriotic War), recruitment advertisements, Russian and Soviet flags etc.
Ukrainian sociologist Volodymyr Ischenger previously told The Paper that after the Russian-Ukrainian conflict broke out, many Western scholars and media focused on the popular mobilization on the Ukrainian side. In order to boost the morale of the Ukrainian side, bottom-up activities of popular organizations to support the front line have been focused on. These folk enthusiasms are not exclusive to Ukraine. In fact, sociological surveys show that some rural areas in Russia outside Moscow and St. Petersburg had wartime patriotic sentiments of similar intensity.
Due to the lack of teachers in the school in Village A, Nikita has to shoulder far more than just teaching English classes. He was from the capital, well-informed and had traveled abroad many times, so the principal asked him to give geography and history classes to the children at the same time.
"At first I thought, isn't it just a basic liberal arts course in junior high school? Nothing difficult to teach, and I can earn more salary. So I agreed. But later it turned out that my idea was too simple." Nikita said .
The “difficulty” Nikita refers to does not mean that the content of junior high school textbooks is difficult, but that it is difficult for teachers to grasp the narrative direction during teaching. As relations with the West become tense, some subtle changes have also taken place in the teaching of history in Russia's basic education.
Nikita considers himself a person who is proud of the history of his country.

title: 普京再当六年俄罗斯总统 | Radio-Canada.ca
translation:
Putin, 71, was re-elected as Russian president without any doubt on Sunday. Official data pointed out that Putin was re-elected with more than 87% of the vote.
Putin's time in the Kremlin, if nothing unexpected happens, will exceed Stalin's 29 years.
Putin said in a speech that his re-election proved that Russia had chosen the right path. He also thanked the soldiers fighting in Ukraine and promised to achieve all his goals if re-elected.
He also rarely mentioned the name of Navalny, the opponent who was the most threatening to him.
He also said that he had agreed to exchange prisoners with Navalny before his death. He said Navalny's main condition in exchange for Russians imprisoned in the West was that they would never return to Russia.
He stated that the protests launched by the opposition would not affect the presidential election, and that those who defaced the ballots would be prosecuted.
Three candidates accompany the race
Officially estimated election turnout was 74.22%, up from 67.5% in the last 2018 election.
None of the other three candidates besides Putin are serious contenders.
Voting took place over three days, with polling stations located in eleven time zones across Russia. It started at 8 am (local time) in the Russian Far East on Friday and ended at 8 pm on Sunday in Kaliningrad (Kaliningrad) on the border with the European Union.
In addition, there are polling stations in illegally annexed areas of Ukraine, online and in certain embassies around the world.
Former Russian President Dmitry Medvedev congratulated Putin on his great victory. Medvedev is currently the No. 2 person on the Russian Security Council. Due to term limits, Putin served as prime minister from 2008 to 2012, with Medvedev serving as president.
Opponents called to polling stations at noon
Navalny's supporters had called on Russians to come to the polls at noon and vote against Putin.
His widow Yulia Navalnaya voted at the Russian Embassy in Berlin, Germany. She said it was impossible to put Navalny's name on the ballot and still be killed a month before the election when Putin's main opponent was in jail.
Leonid Volkov, Navalny's right-hand man who lives in exile in Lithuania, vowed to continue resisting after being attacked last week. His post on X stated that Putin’s fabricated election results were completely divorced from reality and were really not worth talking about.
Some Russian independent media published pictures of invalidated ballots distributed by voters. One of them had the words "Killer and Thief" written on it, and another had the words "Waiting for you in The Hague" written on it. However, some citizens said they were happy to vote for Putin. Dmitri Sergienko, who voted in Moscow, said, "I am very satisfied with everything and I hope everything continues as it is now."
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky accused Putin of falsifying the election results. He wrote on the social network
A spokesperson for the White House National Security Council believes that Putin imprisons opponents and prevents others from running for election; the German Foreign Ministry said that Putin's authoritarian regime is based on censorship, repression and violence.
While opposition activity has been sporadic, at least 77 people have been arrested in Russia over election protests, according to OVD-Info, an NGO that monitors the crackdown.

On March 17, Russia will hold a presidential election, with four candidates running: current Russian President Vladimir Putin, leader of the Liberal Democratic Party Leonid Slutsky, and member of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation Nikolay Harry Tonov, Vladislav Davankov, a member of the New People's Party of Russia.
Putin, 71, has served as Russia's president four times since 2000. Putin first served as President of Russia from 2000 to 2008. After his two terms as president expired in 2008, Medvedev, then Russia's first deputy prime minister, succeeded him as president, and Putin became prime minister of the Russian government.
In 2012, Putin was re-elected as President of Russia after 4 years. According to the newly revised constitution, the term of the Russian President was changed from 4 years to 6 years. In March 2018, Putin won re-election with about 77% of the vote, beginning his fourth presidential term. His current term will end in 2024.
A survey on Putin’s electoral prospects conducted by the Russian opinion polling agency FOM from October 21 to November 13, 2023 among 6,100 respondents showed that the number of respondents who have a positive attitude towards Putin is higher than a few years ago. rise.
When asked whether the current president should be re-elected, the proportion of respondents who answered affirmatively was 33% in 2019, 62% in 2022, and has now risen to 70%.

title: 华语智库:为什么普京能高票胜选连任俄总统？当天他给我国送来“超级大礼”！
translation:
The third is to adjust the diplomatic policy in a timely manner and break the blockade and isolation imposed by the United States and the West for many years.

Over the past 20 years, Russia's foreign policy towards the United States and Western countries has shown great contrast. It has gradually moved from fantasy to rationality and pragmatism.

At the beginning of Putin's rule, he devoted himself to the West. At their core, Russians yearn for the West and return to Europe. In the early days of Putin's administration, he wanted to use the assistance of the United States and Western countries to revitalize Russia and build a strong world. He first visited more than 10 European countries including the United Kingdom. After the "9.11" incident, Putin was the first to call the then US President George W. Bush to express his firm support for the US's fight against terrorism. Subsequently, it provided more assistance to the United States than the total number of NATO member states except the United Kingdom, provided relevant intelligence to the United States in a timely manner, persuaded Central Asian countries to open "air corridors" for US and British military operations, and allowed the US military to use military bases in Central Asian countries. .....Putin’s various good deeds were rewarded with lip service from the United States and Western countries but no real results.

Russia suffered a loss in its diplomacy with the United States and Western countries and was deceived. It promptly returned to the "double-headed eagle" diplomatic policy and turned to balancing the East and the West. While maintaining normal diplomacy with Western countries, it focused on China and India, the two major powers, and established a relationship with China. China has established a comprehensive strategic partnership of coordination for a new era, maintained and developed traditional friendly exchanges with India, and achieved gratifying results.

In 2014, in order to prevent the expansion of the threat of NATO's eastward expansion, Russia decisively took back Crimea, and Russia's relations with the United States and Spain fell into a low point. Since the conflict between Russia and Ukraine, the United States and Western countries have increased their suppression, sanctions and blockade against Russia. Russia timely turned to a comprehensive "Look East", using China as the fulcrum of diplomacy, using the Shanghai Cooperation Organization, BRICS and the Collective Security Treaty Organization as platforms, carrying out active and flexible diplomacy, strengthening exchanges with North Korea, ASEAN and other countries, and taking into account all matters in a timely manner. The southern countries held the Russia-Africa Summit, interacted with many African countries, and continuously developed relations with countries such as Iran, Turkey, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, and Syria, thereby effectively getting rid of diplomatic difficulties. Russia still plays a very important role on the international stage.

title: ﻿普京成功连任 得票率逾87% _大公网
translation:
Putin warns that three wars are only one step away
Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters in the early morning of the 18th, thanking all voters for their support. He said that Russia is a big family, and the results of this election reflect the trust and expectations of voters. The country will further move forward and become stronger, stronger and more efficient. Regarding the negative reaction from Western countries, Putin said: "This is expected. Can you expect them to stand up and applaud?" He also said that the U.S. government is using its power and resources to attack a presidential candidate, and the atmosphere of the U.S. election campaign is becoming increasingly uncivilized and “the whole world is laughing at what’s happening in America.” Russian media said that the US presidential candidate mentioned by Putin was Trump.
When talking about the challenges facing the new term, Putin said that Russia must complete its special military operations in Ukraine. He said that the initiative on the front line is entirely in the hands of the Russian army. When asked about France’s recent statement that it would not rule out the possibility of deploying ground troops in Ukraine and a conflict between Russia and NATO in the future, Putin said: “Everything is possible in the modern world. Everyone knows that (if there is a conflict between Russia and NATO) the distance is World War III is just one step away. I don’t think anyone wants that.”
Putin publicly mentioned opposition figure Navalny's name for the first time in several years. Navalny died in prison last month. Putin said he had considered trading Navalny for prisoners held in the West. "But unfortunately, it happens. What can you do? That's life."
Unite friendly countries to break the Western blockade
After the Russian economy suffered shocks in the early stages of the escalation of the Ukraine crisis, it has gradually shown resilience. However, Western countries' blockade of Russia in the fields of finance, investment, and technological product imports has brought difficulties to the long-term development of the Russian economy. How to continue to hedge against the impact of Western sanctions is an important task for Putin in his new term. Putin said at the end of last month that Russia will vigorously strengthen the development of education, science and technology and other fields, and let technological independence become the driving force for industrial upgrading to improve economic efficiency and competitiveness.
Russian experts believe that resisting Western containment and suppression, uniting friendly countries, and achieving established diplomatic goals will become the focus of Putin's future foreign policy. Kortunov, an expert at the Russian Council for International Affairs, said that in the coming period, Russia and the United States will continue to have in-depth confrontation, but both sides will still maintain a certain degree of restraint to avoid accidents such as nuclear war.
Mukhin, director of the Russian Political Information Center, said that Russia will continue to play an important role within frameworks such as the BRICS cooperation mechanism and the Shanghai Cooperation Organization.

translation:
What was the result of the election?
The statistics of 100% of the votes released on the 18th showed that Putin won 87.28% of the votes and won re-election again with a record advantage. The electoral turnout exceeded 73%, setting a record for contemporary Russian elections.

What do the election results show?
Russian voters said that Putin has rich experience and can enable Russia to continue to develop in today's difficult environment. Experts pointed out that Putin is Russia's "crisis manager" and the Russian people do not want to see a change in leadership during the conflict between Russia and Ukraine.

What is the reaction of the international community?
China, Cuba, North Korea, Bolivia and other countries congratulated Putin. Catholic Pope Francis also congratulated Putin on his re-election as president of Russia. Ukraine, the United States, Germany, the United Kingdom and other countries accused the Russian election of being "unfair."

What did Putin say?
Putin thanked all voters for their support and emphasized that Russia will move forward and become more solid, stronger and more efficient.
Regarding Sino-Russian relations, Putin said that the relations between the two countries will continue to deepen and develop and benefit the two peoples.
Regarding the conflict between Russia and Ukraine, Putin said that the initiative lies entirely in the hands of the Russian military and reiterated Russia’s support for peace negotiations. He warned that if a direct conflict breaks out between NATO and Russia, it will be just one step away from world war.

title: Итоги выборов-2024: Путин побеждает с рекордными результатом и явкой в истории РФ
translation:
The presidential elections in Russia are over. Incumbent President Vladimir Putin wins with more than 87% of the vote. Federal turnout, including remote voting, exceeded 74%. These preliminary data are reported by the Central Election Commission.

State sociological services published the first results of exit polls at 21:00 Moscow time - by this hour all polling stations in Russia were closed. All exit polls showed a landslide victory for Vladimir Putin, who is running for a fifth term.

According to the results of the VTsIOM exit poll, Vladimir Putin received 87% of the votes. The FOM exit poll gives him even more - 87.8% of the votes.

In the previous elections, in 2018, Vladimir Putin won with a final result of 76.69%.

Exit polls gave second place to the candidate from the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, 75-year-old deputy Nikolai Kharitonov. According to the VTsIOM exit poll, he received 4.6% of the votes (FOM gave him 4.7% of the votes).

In third place is Deputy Speaker of the Duma, candidate from “New People” Vyacheslav Davankov. According to VTsIOM, he received 4.2% of the vote. FOM gives him 3.6% of the total number of voters.

Finally, both exit polls give the last place to the head of the LDPR, Leonid Slutsky. VTsIOM - 3% of votes, FOM - 2.5%.

The official results of the elections are also summed up by the Central Election Commission. By 3 a.m. Moscow time, the commission reported that more than 90% of the protocols had been processed. According to these preliminary results, Vladimir Putin received 87.21% of the votes, Kharitonov - 4.28%, Davankov - 3.93%, and Slutsky - 3.16%.
input:

translation:
How does voting work abroad?
Polling stations are open in 144 countries, but they do not have uniform opening hours. In some countries, fewer polling stations have opened this time than in the 2018 presidential elections. This is due to a reduction in the number of diplomats and consular offices. So, in Germany, instead of 15 polling stations, there will be two (at the embassy in Berlin and the consulate in Bonn), CEC member Nikolai Bulaev gave an example.

The Latvian authorities warned that they will check the documents confirming the right to stay in the country of Russians who come to vote at the embassy in Riga. The authorities of neighboring Estonia stated that they do not intend to do this.

By March 13, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, 40 thousand people voted early.

title: Выборы президента России. Главное
translation:
Who monitors violations
During the elections, video surveillance was organized at precinct and territorial election commissions. The broadcast from the cameras goes to a service portal, access to which is available to election commissions of all levels, representatives of registered candidates and parties that nominated them, observers from public chambers, the Commissioner for Human Rights, representatives of the Human Rights Council, and the Ministry of Digital Development.

Observers from candidates, representatives of Russian public organizations, and international observers will also monitor the voting process. Citizens and organizations declared to be foreign agents do not have the right to monitor the voting process; in particular, there will be no observers from the “Voice” movement at the polling stations (included in the register of foreign agents in 2021).

Observers from the OSCE Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights were not invited to the elections. The Foreign Ministry stated that the organization is biased and politicized in its assessments. “The absence of OSCE/ODIHR representatives will not in any way affect the quality of international observation,” the Foreign Ministry assured, since more than a thousand international observers from almost a hundred foreign states and various international organizations have been invited. In particular, there will be observation missions from the Commonwealth of Independent States and the Shanghai Cooperation Organization.
