title: 俄罗斯大选2024·特写｜堡垒、新领土和“变得更像俄罗斯”的小村庄
translation:
Nikita, a 38-year-old Moscow native, was once a senior white-collar worker in a multinational financial company. After the conflict between Russia and Ukraine broke out, he became a "rebel" among people of his age and in the same circle.
At the beginning of spring 2022, Nikita saw the turmoil in the surrounding work environment. Many young colleagues want to find another way out: some of them try to change jobs to local companies in Russia; some continue to stay; and some try to go abroad. Even if they cannot go to Western Europe in one step, they can first move to Montenegro, Turkey and other countries , and then make new plans.
But these roads have no special appeal to Nikita. He is tired of the reinforced concrete jungle in Moscow's CBD. As early as before the war, he had longed to live in the countryside for a long time. The war that broke out in 2022 made him make his final determination. Seeing everyone planning their own way forward, he didn't think much about it and didn't even inform his family before setting off.
"At that time, I was bombarded with information from the media and the Telegram channel every day. Later, the news of partial mobilization also made people panic. I thought that I could be clean by going to the countryside, so I resigned from my job without discussing it with anyone. The luggage is gone.”
input: The outbreak of the Russia-Ukraine conflict.

title: 习近平电贺普京“当选连任”，传北京考虑参加瑞士举行的乌克兰和会
translation:
We are convinced that under the strategic guidance of President Xi Jinping and President Putin, China-Russia relations will continue to move forward," Lin Jian, the new spokesperson of the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said at a regular press conference on Monday.
Although China has been quietly providing diplomatic support and economic assistance to Russia after Russia's invasion of Ukraine was severely sanctioned by the West, the Beijing authorities have not forgotten to make high-profile calls for a "ceasefire and an end to the war" in Ukraine. Li Hui, the Chinese government's special representative for Eurasian affairs, has visited Russia, Ukraine and many European countries twice, claiming to be a thread for peace.

However, because China's peace proposal does not address the key demand of Russia's withdrawal from occupied Ukrainian territories, Kyiv and its Western allies are not particularly optimistic about Beijing's mediation efforts.

China's ambassador to Switzerland Wang Shiting said in an interview with Swiss media on Monday that Beijing was considering participating in a peace conference that Switzerland will host in a few months to end the war in Ukraine.

"We must prevent the crisis from worsening or even getting out of control," Reuters quoted Wang Shiting as saying. “We are closely following the upcoming Ukraine conference in Switzerland and are examining the possibility of participating.”

The Swiss government first proposed the idea of ​​hosting the Ukraine peace conference in January this year. Based on current progress, the conference is likely to be held this summer.

Since the Swiss government did not plan to invite Moscow to the meeting, the Kremlin claimed that the meeting was "meaningless" and would definitely fail without Russia's participation.

Swiss President Viola Amherd said last month that she doubted Russia would be included in peace talks from the start.

Wang Shiting said in an interview with the media that China has proposed a strategy for a political settlement of the Ukrainian conflict.

"The territorial sovereignty of all countries must be respected and the United Nations Charter must be upheld," he said.

"We should support Russia and Ukraine in resuming direct dialogue as soon as possible so that the situation can gradually cool down," Wang Shiting added.
input:
Conviction that China-Russia relations will strengthen under the guidance of President Xi Jinping and President Putin.
Russia's progression and strengthening.
Providing support.
The invasion of Ukraine by Russia.
Russian illegal occupation of Ukrainian territories.
The Ukraine crisis involving Russia and Western sanctions.
Including occupied and annexed territories in Russian elections.

title: 俄罗斯大选在即，“除了普京还有谁”的思维在弥漫 - BBC News 中文
translation:
In an exhibition hall opposite the Kremlin, Vladimir Putin took to the stage.
The audience stood up and applauded like thunder.
The invited guests include many Russian celebrities who support Putin's bid for a fifth term in March's presidential election. The audience here is very happy.
"(Putin) is an extraordinary leader, the most courageous and wise man." Film director Andrei Konchalovsky said happily.
"The Russian people have never been so united in supporting their president," said national singer Nadezhda Babkina. "Anyone who tries to stop this will fail."
The event, and the high-profile expressions of support from celebrities, seemed to be an attempt to show that candidate Putin has his own organization: the Putin Super League.
But be aware, this is a league he founded and runs. Russia's political system is Putin's political system, and his rules of the game are his elections.
Putin's sharpest critics have long since been "downgraded" and either exiled abroad or imprisoned.
Therefore, elections here are easy to predict.
But this is not always the case.
Thirty years ago, I remember watching the first election night broadcast on Russian television in Moscow - it was a parliamentary election and no one knew who was going to win.
I will never forget when they brought in astrologers to make political predictions. That's actually appropriate, because 30 years ago, Russians had stars shining in their eyes about democracy, freedom and the future of their country.
For today's Russian election, you don't need an astrologer or a crystal ball. I can tell you the results of the 2024 presidential election right now: Putin won a resounding victory.
Why so confident?
First, while Putin will not be the only name on the ballot, the challenger will not have his old enemies, including jailed opposition leader Alexei Navalny. Putin versus Navalny? This is not allowed in the Putin Super League.
True, another Kremlin critic, Boris Nadezhdin, is also pushing for a vote. But Naderzdin is not Navalny, he is careful about his criticism of Putin and is believed to have connections within the presidential palace.
If he ends up running, it will be because the Kremlin believes it is in Putin's interest to have a critical challenger.
Secondly, in Russia the government controls television stations. Putin gets a lot of air time, and he is praised on television and rarely criticized: convenient for those seeking re-election.
input:
Yulia Navalnaya being applauded at a protest in Berlin.
Exile of Putin's political opponents.
Imprisonment of political opponents by Putin.
Broadcast of a Russian election event.
Jailing of political opponents by Putin.
Public criticism of Putin and his war in Ukraine.

title: Путин побеждает с 87,28 % голосов: как прошли самые скандальные выборы в истории России. Главные итоги выборов президента России 2024
translation: And finally, about the features of our elections. On March 17, at PEC No. 1136 in the Krasnoselsky district of St. Petersburg, an incident occurred at a polling station. The police tied up the St. Petersburg resident along with his ballot while he was voting in a booth. The vigilant law enforcement officer suspected that the man was writing something on the ballot, most likely offensive, and decided to stop the emerging “crime.” The St. Petersburg resident was lucky; he was saved by the chairman of the precinct election commission, who reminded the zealous law enforcement officers about the secrecy of voting. That is, the Criminal Code of the Russian Federation Article 141. Obstruction of the exercise of electoral rights or the work of election commissions. Indeed, the man was lucky, but he could have been shot (just kidding).

title: 普京无悬念胜选 演说提与习近平友谊 | 德国之声 来自德国 介绍德国 | DW | 18.03.2024
translation:
According to Russian official exit polls released on Sunday (March 18), the turnout for this presidential election was about 74.2%, and current President Putin received an overwhelming vote of more than 87%, which will make Putin, who has been in power for nearly 25 years, , was able to move towards the fifth presidential term, and surpassed Stalin's record, becoming the Russian leader with the longest reign in more than 200 years.
This is the highest vote rate in the post-Soviet era; the last Russian presidential election was in 2018, when there was a turnout of 67.5%, and Putin received 76.7% of the votes. However, there is no real opposition candidate in this election, so the outcome is not in doubt.
After the exit polls were released, Putin gave a speech in Moscow to thank the Russian people and said that the "grand plans" he had set for different fields before the election "will definitely be realized."
"No matter how much someone wants to suppress us and attack our will and consciousness, no one has ever succeeded in history, has never succeeded so far, and will not in the future." Putin also said that Russia does not rule out launching a full-scale conflict with NATO; if If so, "we are only one step away from a full-scale World War III... I believe no one would want this."
When Putin mentioned China, he emphasized that the interests of Russia and China coincided with each other. Russia-China relations will become stronger in the next few years, and his "personal friendship" with Chinese President Xi Jinping will also help the relations between the two countries continue to develop steadily.
On the one hand, Putin praised China's success on the world stage, but on the other hand, he claimed that provocations and sanctions against China are "doomed to fail." He should also agree with China's position and advocate that "Taiwan is part of China."
input:
Putin surpassing Stalin as Russia's longest-serving leader.
Putin thanking Russian voters in a speech.
Suppressing Russia.
Attempts to suppress the will of Russians.
The development of bilateral relations between China and Russia.
Western attempts to create provocations.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜选票上，除了普京还有谁？
translation:
In late January, queues began to form at Nadezhdin’s signature collection points. On January 31, Nadezdin said he had submitted 105,000 signatures to the Central Election Commission.
Russia's Central Election Commission stated on February 8 that 9,147 of the signatures collected by Nadezdin were invalid. Among them, the voter data of 858 signatures was unreliable, and 11 other signatures were found to have passed away. Therefore, Nadezhdin received only about 95,000 valid signatures and was not qualified to run.
Duntsova
Duntsova was born in Krasnoyarsk, Siberia, in 1983. She later moved with her family to Rzhev, Tver Region, and studied law and television journalism at a local university. In 2003, Duntsova started her career at Rzhev City Television. After a year of work, Duntsova worked as the head of a television studio at a school, and then started an independent television company with her husband. She became a member of the Rzhev City Duma in 2019.
In November 2023, Duntsova announced on social platforms that she would participate in the Russian presidential election and announced her campaign website. As an independent candidate, Duntsova must assemble an advocacy group of no less than 500 people and collect at least 300,000 signatures from supporters in 40 or more regions. On December 23, 2023, Russia’s Central Election Commission announced that Duntsova’s qualification to run was rejected due to many substandard errors in the submitted materials.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜五个“首次”，这场选举有何特殊？
translation:
For those who meet the regulations and intend to participate in the presidential election, they can participate in the election through two methods: party nomination and self-recommendation.
There are two situations in this method of party nomination. The first category is the political parties that have entered the Russian State Duma, currently including the United Russia Party, the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, the Russian Liberal Democratic Party, the Public Russia Party (the "Just Russia-Patriots-For Truth" Party) and the New People's Party. Candidates nominated by the above-mentioned political parties will be registered directly as candidates. For other political parties that have not entered the Russian State Duma, candidates nominated by them need to collect the signatures of 100,000 supporters and submit them to the Russian Central Committee for review.
For self-recommended candidates, obtaining qualifications is more complicated. It first needs to convene an initiative group of no less than 500 people. The group participants must vote by majority to approve the self-recommended person's candidacy. It also needs to collect the signatures of at least 300,000 supporters from 40 or more regions. Candidates can be registered only after the review by the Russian-Chinese Election Commission.
Among the four candidates for the 2024 Russian general election, only Putin is an independent candidate and qualified to run through self-recommendation. The remaining three people were nominated by the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia, the Russian Communist Party, and the New People's Party.
According to previous reports from Xinhua News Agency, Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, announced at a press conference on January 29 this year that Putin had been officially registered as a candidate for the 2024 presidential election. Among the approximately 315,000 signatures of supporters submitted by Putin’s campaign headquarters, the Central Election Commission randomly selected 60,000 signatures for verification. The results showed that 91 signatures were invalid and complied with the relevant regulations for registering as a candidate for the presidential election.

title: 普京：乌军进攻俄本土试图扰乱俄总统选举投票
translation:
Russian President Vladimir Putin said on the 15th that the Ukrainian army had repeatedly attempted to attack the Russian mainland in recent days without success, and that the Ukrainian army was trying to disrupt the Russian presidential election voting through attacks.
Putin held a video meeting with members of the Russian Security Council that day and said that since the 12th, Ukraine has mainly used special forces, foreign mercenaries and Ukrainian army support forces to try to enter Russian territory many times and cause many sabotages and terrorist attacks. Incidents, four of which occurred in the direction of Belgorod and one in the direction of Kursk.
Putin said that the Ukrainian army used more than 2,500 men, 35 tanks and 40 armored vehicles for this purpose, but failed, and as a result, it lost 60% of its personnel and more than 50% of its armored equipment.
He also emphasized that the above-mentioned actions of the Ukrainian army are "meaningless" from a military perspective and "criminal acts" from a humanitarian perspective. Their purpose is to disrupt the Russian presidential election voting process and "terrorize Russian civilians in areas bordering Ukraine" ".
The Russian Ministry of Defense issued a report on the 15th stating that from the 12th to the 14th, the Russian Armed Forces and the border defense department of the Russian Federal Security Service jointly defeated the actions of Ukrainian armed personnel to break into the territory of Russia’s Belgorod and Kursk regions. More than 1,500 soldiers were lost in the operation, about 500 of whom were killed, and 18 tanks and 23 armored vehicles were destroyed.
Official voting for the 2024 Russian presidential election will be held from the 15th to the 17th. According to the Russian President’s website, Putin participated in the presidential election vote online on the 15th.
input:
Entering Russian territory.

The event where various groups lost personnel and military equipment.
Ukrainian armed forces attempting to break into Russian territory.
Killing of two people in Belgorod.
Destruction of various targets by different actors.

title: 中俄独裁者互祝连任 “友谊”会突变吗？ | 普京 | 习近平 | 俄罗斯 | 大纪元
translation:
The two countries are politically authoritarian, and Xi Jinping also refers to many of Putin's practices.
Lai Rongwei said that under the siege of a democratic society, the CCP needs a cooperative partner. While Putin is deeply involved in the war in Ukraine and Russia is sanctioned by Western society, the economic complementarity between Russia and China is now higher than before.
The Russia-Ukraine war, which has lasted for more than two years, is still in a stalemate. Last month, China confirmed that Putin will visit China again this year. This will be Putin's 19th visit to China since taking power in Russia.
According to statistics from the General Administration of Customs of the Communist Party of China, in 2022, the bilateral trade volume between China and Russia reached a record high of 190.27 billion U.S. dollars, a year-on-year increase of 29.3%. When the Russo-Ukrainian war broke out and Russia faced sanctions from Western societies, China became Russia's most important trading partner.
After the Russian presidential election, Putin warned on March 18 that if Russia had a direct conflict with NATO, it would be only one step away from the so-called World War III. The European Union issued another warning to Putin and determined to continue supporting Ukraine.
Lai Rongwei said that anyone can say cruel things like Putin, just like Kim Jong-un who talks about blowing up South Korea all day long. This is just a kind of intimidation. But the international community must also unite and collectively deter it. Just like Taiwan wants to deter the CCP, the best way is to unite all Taiwanese friends.
On March 22, 2023, Xi Jinping ended his three-day visit to Russia. When leaving the Kremlin, he said something to Putin, saying that "we will promote the so-called changes in a century together." Putin responded in agreement. At that time, outsiders believed that what Xi was hinting at was an attempt to join forces to disrupt the "world order."
Lai Rongwei said that the two authoritarian regimes of China and Russia are now joining forces to overthrow the international order, and their main enemies are the United States and the European Union.
Weng Mingxian said that there is another influencing factor in the so-called century-old changes, that is, the US presidential election will be held on November 5. If Biden is elected, it will continue to create a tense situation in which the United States has to deal with the strategic alliance between China and Russia. But another variable is that if Trump is elected, with Trump’s leadership style, he may put the United States first to implement global strategy, which will also pose another risk to the so-called global strategic pattern of China and Russia.
Lai Rongwei said that no matter whether Trump or Biden is president of the United States, the confrontation between Russia and NATO and the confrontation between the United States and China will continue.
He analyzed that because China and Russia are considered to be the evil camp, this points to confrontation with the West in terms of values. For example, the United States often names Russia and China for interfering in their elections, and Taiwan has also been talking about the CCP's cognitive warfare. Both China and Russia are using vague spaces and techniques to change the status quo, and are using the values ​​of Western liberal democracy and the normal state of economic freedom to carry out their conspiratorial infiltration. The international community should be vigilant in this regard.

Year-on-year increase in economic indicators for China-Russia trade and Russian economy.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·专访｜科尔图诺夫：存在与北约发生直接冲突的可能
translation:
Today, many communication channels between Russia and NATO have failed, making the situation even more serious. If there is a direct military conflict between Russia and NATO, it is likely to reach the level of nuclear war. Therefore, such conflicts must be prevented at all costs. 
Putin’s Next Six Years: Regime Transition, Economic Development and Sustained Peace
The Paper: Recently, we talked with many ordinary Russians about their feelings about the war. We found that many Russians wanted to see the war end as quickly as possible. How do you view the impact of this sentiment on the social and political situation in Russia?
Andrei Kortunov: Of course, we all want to end special military operations as soon as possible. The question is, under what conditions is Russia acceptable to end this operation. Russian society is divided into "hawks" and "doves". The "hawks" demand that "the war must be completely victorious," while the "doves" believe that it is necessary to start peace negotiations as soon as possible. But these discussions had little impact on the sociopolitical situation in Russia, as they were mainly conducted at the expert level.
The Paper: Putin is entering his fifth term. What challenges will he face and what tasks will he need to complete in the next six years? Which of them are the most urgent and critical?
Andrei Kortunov: Nowadays, the political tenure of politicians can be very long. But assuming that this presidential term is likely to be Putin's last, then Putin's main challenge is to strengthen state institutions and ensure a smooth and less painful transition to a new generation of political leaders.
Of course, another challenge is to formulate and implement a new model of national socio-economic development so that Russia can integrate into the ongoing Fourth Industrial Revolution (note: driven by technological innovations represented by artificial intelligence, big data, cloud computing, biotechnology, etc. , a new round of industrial revolution marked by intelligence) and the future global economy emerging in the process. And also to end the conflict with Ukraine and the West - at least the most damaging military conflict in the heart of Europe. Without sustained peace, any other strategic goal will be difficult to achieve.
input:
Discussions among various groups and platforms.
Promotion of national development by Vladimir Putin.

title: 路透：普京“胜选连任”后五月将访华与习近平举行峰会
translation:
Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov, when asked about Reuters reports about Putin's upcoming visit to China, said that information about Putin's visit will be released closer to the date.
"We are currently planning several presidential visits and several high-level contacts," Peskov told reporters. "We will let you know as the date approaches."
After Putin brazenly invaded Ukraine in February 2022, Russia was strongly condemned by the United States and Western allies and imposed rounds of severe sanctions. However, Beijing not only failed to accuse Moscow of its aggressive actions, but instead took the opportunity to strengthen political, diplomatic, and economic and trade relations with Russia, and even bought energy products that Russia was forced to sell at a discount due to Western sanctions.
Before launching the war in Ukraine, Putin made a special visit to Beijing and signed a series of cooperation documents with Xi Jinping known as "unlimited". China and Russia have obvious intentions of holding back-to-back to warm up in the face of resistance from the United States and the West.
The United States currently positions China as its biggest strategic competitor and views Russia as the country that poses the greatest threat. President Biden has repeatedly stated that competition and confrontation between the two camps of democracy and authoritarianism will continue throughout the 21st century.
Reuters reported that Xi Jinping and Putin share the same world view and both view the West as decadent and declining, while China is challenging the United States’ hegemony in many fields, including almost everything from quantum computing to synthetic biology to military technology and power. .
Putin is scheduled to hold a new presidential inauguration around May 7. Western diplomats and observers have long predicted that Putin would choose Beijing as the first stop of his overseas trip during his new term.
Putin told reporters on Sunday that Russia and China have similar views on global affairs and that their relationship is highly resilient because of his close personal relationship with Xi. Putin said that Moscow and Beijing will further deepen their bilateral relations in the coming years.
Xi Jinping also visited Moscow in March last year, shortly after breaking with decades of CCP practice to seek a third term. Putin and Xi Jinping often boast of their close relationship and have met more than 40 times. The last time Putin and Xi Jinping met was in October last year, when Putin went to Beijing to attend the Belt and Road Forum.
China has been quietly providing diplomatic support and economic assistance to Russia after Russia was severely sanctioned by the West for its invasion of Ukraine. However, the Beijing authorities have also not forgotten to make high-profile calls for a "ceasefire and an end to the war" in Ukraine. Li Hui, the Chinese government's special representative for Eurasian affairs, has visited Russia, Ukraine and many European countries twice, claiming to be a thread for peace. However, because China's peace proposal does not address the key demand of Russia's withdrawal from occupied Ukrainian territories, Kyiv and its Western allies are not particularly optimistic about Beijing's mediation efforts.
China's ambassador to Switzerland Wang Shiting said in an interview with Swiss media on Monday that Beijing was considering participating in a peace conference that Switzerland will host in a few months to end the war in Ukraine.

title: 新京报 - 好新闻，无止境
translation:
In the early morning of March 18, local time, a few hours after the voting for Russia’s eighth presidential election ended, the results were basically clear. Preliminary vote counting data released by Russia's Central Election Commission showed that out of about 95% of the votes counted, current President Putin won more than 87% of the votes. This means that Putin has actually won the election and locked in the position of the next Russian president.
 
This result is not surprising. Since there is no strong competitor, before the election, it was widely predicted that Putin would easily win the presidential election. Judging from the current results, this is also true. Putin's three challengers all received less than 5% of the vote. Putin delivered a victory speech in the early morning of the 18th. He thanked voters for their support and stated that he would continue to promote national development during his new term.
 
overwhelming victory
 
According to Russia's TASS news agency, the latest vote counting results from Russia's Central Election Commission showed that independent candidate Putin won 87.32% of the 95.08% votes that had been counted, achieving an overwhelming victory.
 
In second place was Nikolai Kharitonov of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, who received 4.28% of the votes. The candidate of the Russian New People's Party Vladislav Davankov ranked third with 3.85% of the vote. The candidate of the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia, Leonid Slutsky, ranked fourth with 3.15% of the vote.


Live statistics of the presidential election are shown on a screen captured on the streets of the Russian capital Moscow on March 17. Xinhua News Agency
 
According to Russian presidential election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes in the election is elected president. The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the results of the presidential election before March 28 and announce them within 3 days after the election results are confirmed.
 
After the preliminary election results came out, Putin delivered a victory speech at his campaign headquarters. According to "Russia Today", Putin pointed out in his speech that Russia is currently facing many challenges, but as long as the Russian people remain united, they can overcome all challenges.
 
He thanked Russian voters for their trust in him, saying "I will do my best to complete the tasks facing the country and achieve the goals that we all consider to be the highest priority." He also said that all major tasks for national development have been spelled out in the recent State of the Nation Address to both houses of parliament and that he will do his best to accomplish the set goals.
input:
The predictable outcome of the Russian election.
Putin delivering a speech.
Putin thanking Russian voters in a speech.
Promotion of national development by Vladimir Putin.
Preliminary rigged election results showing Vladimir Putin receiving approximately 87% of the vote.
Overcoming challenges and difficulties in Russia.
State of the Nation Address outlining national development goals.

title: 普京胜选表态:竭尽所能实现国家主要任务和目标
translation:
China News Service, Moscow, March 18 (Reporter Tian Bing) Russian presidential candidate and current President Vladimir Putin said at his first press conference after the election voting on the 18th that he would do his best to achieve the country's main tasks and goals.
At 7:00 a.m. Moscow time on the 18th, the Russian Central Election Commission announced the counting results of 99.43% of the votes. Putin won 87.32% of the support in the 2024 presidential election. Putin has actually won the election.
Kharitonov, the candidate nominated by the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, received 4.32% of the votes, Davankov, the candidate nominated by the Russian New People's Party, received 3.79% of the votes, and Slutsky, the candidate nominated by the Russian Liberal Democratic Party, received 3.19% of the votes.
Putin came to the campaign headquarters near the Kremlin to deliver a speech in the early morning of the 18th, and then held a press conference.
Putin said that the source of Russian power is the people, and the votes of every Russian citizen constitute the unified will of the people. He will continue to promote national development in his new term.
Putin pointed out that all the main tasks and goals of Russia's development have been elaborated in the recent State of the Union address to both houses of parliament, and he will do his best to achieve the set goals. Russia will move forward and become stronger, more powerful and more efficient.
Regarding the Ukrainian issue, Putin stated that the initiative on the frontline of the special military operation against Ukraine lies entirely in the hands of the Russian army. The issue of special military operations and strengthening Russia's defense capabilities are one of the main tasks of his new term. He said that Russia supports peace negotiations, but not just because the other side is running out of bullets, but if they truly, seriously and long-term hope that the two countries can establish peace, Russia supports negotiations on the Ukrainian issue. "This is a very serious issue."
Putin also said that considering the Ukrainian army's attacks on Russia's Belgorod region and other places, Russia does not rule out the possibility of establishing a "safe zone" in the border area at some point.
Regarding the United States, Putin once again stated that Russia has no preference for any American presidential candidate and that Russia is ready to cooperate with any American leader that American voters vote for.
When answering the question of whether a full-scale conflict between Russia and NATO is possible and how likely it is, Putin said, "Everything is possible in the modern world." He pointed out that there are currently military personnel from NATO countries in Ukraine, and they are "dying in large numbers."
Regarding Sino-Russian relations, Putin said that after years of development, Russia-China relations are very stable and highly complementary. Putin pointed out that Russia and China have many points of convergence in economic, diplomatic and other fields. As far as the development of the Eurasian region is concerned, Russia-China relations are an important stabilizing factor, and the joint construction of the "Belt and Road" initiative proposed by China is very important.
Putin spoke positively of China's development achievements. He believes that China is achieving rapid development with great confidence and transforming into an innovative economy; China is increasingly active on the international stage and has achieved great success, and has many friends around the world.
Putin emphasized that Taiwan is an inalienable part of China; those who seek provocation around Taiwan and take various measures to delay China's development will undoubtedly fail completely.
Official voting for Russia’s eighth presidential election will be held from the 15th to the 17th. The Russian-Chinese Election Commission announced that it will confirm the final results of this presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within three days after confirmation.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜普京获近九成选票，胜选后抨击美式民主
translation:
At noon on March 17, some Russian voters went to the polling station after receiving a call from Navalny’s widow, Yulia Navalnaya, and queues formed in front of several polling stations in Moscow and other Russian cities. There was a long queue.
Yulia Navalnaya herself appeared in front of the Russian Embassy in Germany, urging her supporters to show up en masse. According to reports, more than 2,000 voters participated in a protest outside the Russian Embassy in Germany at noon on the 17th.
"You gave me hope that everything was not in vain and we will still fight." Navalnaya said in a post on the 17th that he wrote "Navalny" on the ballot.
In the past few days, people in Russia also carried out protests, including pouring dye into ballot boxes and setting fire to attack polling stations.
Ella Pamfilova, chairwoman of Russia's Central Election Commission, said on the 16th that "a total of at least 214 ballots have been irreparably damaged due to voters trying to pour various liquids into the ballot boxes."
Pamfilova also said that 29 polling stations in at least 20 regions in Russia reported attempts to sabotage ballots: 20 polling stations reported attempts to pour liquid into ballot boxes, and 8 polling stations reported attempts to sabotage ballots. There were attempts at arson and one polling station reported attempts at throwing smoke grenades.
Dmitry Medvedev, deputy chairman of the National Security Council of the Russian Federation, chairman of the United Russia party and former Russian president, said the perpetrators may face treason charges, which could lead to a maximum sentence of 20 years in prison. The Russian Interior Ministry stated that 155 administrative charges have been filed during the 2024 presidential election and 61 criminal cases have been opened, including 21 cases of obstructing voters' rights.
input:
Dissatisfied Russians forming long lines outside diplomatic missions around noon.
Navalny's associates urged anti-Putin and anti-war individuals to vote at noon on Sunday.
Ukrainian sabotage attempts involving special forces, foreign mercenaries, and reconnaissance groups.
Throwing objects at Russian election-related sites.
Filing of administrative and criminal charges in Russia.

title: 枪口之下：被占地区的乌克兰人在俄罗斯选举中支持普京 | 政治 新闻 | 半岛电视台
translation:
Moscow-appointed “governors” publicly urged residents of the occupied areas to vote for Putin.
"I believe that the activity of our citizens will be very active and every resident of the region will vote for our president," Yevgeny Balitsky, the Russian-appointed governor of Zaporozhye, said on Telegram.
On Friday morning, Russian officials reported early voting rates - 45% in the occupied Zaporozhye region and 58% in the Donetsk and Kherson regions.
RIA Novosti submitted the report at 8:05 a.m. that day, five minutes after polling stations opened at public schools and government buildings in the occupied areas.
The election provides the Kremlin with an opportunity to create an illusion for the state-controlled media and its Russian audience.
"The authorities organized large crowds who were happy to pose for videos to provide beautiful photos. They did not need to force anyone to vote. No one was going to cause riots," said the former Enel Godard resident Said so.
Russia even allowed those who had not yet obtained a red Russian passport to vote, in flagrant violation of Russia's own electoral laws.
Those who want to vote can present any valid ID, including a Ukrainian passport or driving license.
Russia has unveiled strict security measures over what it calls "information transfers" from Ukraine.
Russian reports say Ukrainian intelligence services collected voter information and issued threats to election officials.
The threats "appear to have been copied and pasted, with only some words changed," Vladimir Vysotsky, the chief electoral official in the Russian-occupied Donetsk region, told the TASS news agency.
Ella Pamfilova, Russia’s chief electoral official, said on Thursday, “For the first time we are holding an election under such complex and extreme circumstances, with such a bad international situation, constant threats, and a lot of other negative factors. "
Meanwhile, Ukrainian observers are loudly questioning the need for elections in Russia, as Putin becomes Russia's longest-serving leader since Soviet ruler Joseph Stalin.
Svetlana Chunikina, vice-president of the Association of Political Psychologists in Kyiv, said: “Putin’s fanatical insistence on prolonging his interminable rhythm through ‘elections’ while completely eliminating the competitive and open-ended nature of the This reflects the deep divisions that exist in totalitarian reality.”
“In Russia, they see elections as the most prestigious way to legitimize power,” she told Al Jazeera. “But totalitarian reality does not generate any prestige. It only generates fear and compliance.”
Ukraine predictably harshly condemned the vote in the occupied territories.
Ukraine’s Foreign Ministry said in a statement on Thursday that “activities that imitate the presidential election demonstrate Russia’s further disregard for the standards and principles of international law.”

title: 再干6年，普京能带出一个强大的俄罗斯吗？
translation:
On March 17, local time, Putin delivered a speech to the media at the campaign headquarters. Picture from Visual China


Liu Jun, vice president of the China Society of International Relations and executive director of the Russian Studies Center at East China Normal University, believes: "Overall, Putin's governance over the past 20 years has been relatively successful. He has brought Russia out of the decline that followed the collapse of the Soviet Union in the 1990s. ”


From an economic point of view, Russia is far from being considered a powerful country, but its political and military strength must not be underestimated in today's international society.


Putin mentioned in his State of the Union address that Russia is now the largest economy in Europe and the fifth largest economy in the world based on purchasing power parity, and will become one of the world's four major economic powers in the near future.


"Putin is very confident, and he will be even more confident in the future." Liu Jun said that this confidence comes from his successful governance over the past 20 years, the smooth advancement of the Crimea issue and special military operations, and of course, his high vote in the Russian election.


Liu Jun believes that in the next 6 or 12 years, “Putin will continue to consolidate Russia’s core leadership position in the post-Soviet space; actively promote and implement his ‘turn east’ strategy; and will not rule out the relationship between Russia and the West. "It will slowly thaw. Although it is difficult to thaw Russia-US relations, it is possible to strengthen contacts with Europe."


Hao He, associate researcher at the Institute of Russian, Eastern European and Central Asian Studies at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, believes that what Russia will do in the next 6 to 12 years will depend more on what the world will become. "Because it is not very likely that Russia will achieve particularly great economic achievements through a radical transformation of its model, but at a time of major changes unseen in a century, changes in the world may bring some new opportunities to Russia."


Why did Putin focus on the "people's livelihood card" during the election campaign?


The Russian general election was held as scheduled against the backdrop of the Russia-Ukraine conflict.


This is Russia's first wartime election, and it is also the first time Russia has held presidential election voting in the four "new regions" of Donetsk, Luhansk, Zaporozhie and Kherson. All four regions are currently in a state of war. Prior to this, Ukraine declared wartime cancellation of presidential elections.





On March 17, local time, people in the Luhansk region participated in voting in the Russian presidential election.

title: Путин побеждает с 87,28 % голосов: как прошли самые скандальные выборы в истории России. Главные итоги выборов президента России 2024
translation:
Record turnout, violations and international isolation: the main results of the 2024 Russian presidential elections
Let's start with the main thing - voter turnout. More than 77% of Russians went to the polling stations or voted online - this is an absolute record in the entire history of presidential elections in the country. In some regions, such as Chechnya, Tuva and the Kemerovo region, turnout went beyond 90%. Chechnya especially “distinguished itself” in this regard, where 98.99% allegedly voted for Putin. Independent exit polls showed much more modest figures for support for the incumbent president - from 55% to 76%.

This excitement is explained by several factors.

Firstly, the “Crimean consensus” and patriotic upsurge against the background of the confrontation with the West played a role. Many Russians see Putin as a defender of national interests and a guarantor of stability in difficult times. Secondly, we cannot discount the administrative resource and the mobilization of state employees, security forces and other groups of the population loyal to the authorities.

Here, as an example, look, students of Volgograd Medical University “on their own, without orders, completely by accident” gathered and came in a friendly line to vote, as “usually happens” with all students. It just happened that way.

translation:
Voting in Russia's presidential election entered its third day on Sunday, with current President Vladimir Putin expected to win an overwhelming majority of votes, automatically ending the election without entering a second round.
If this happens, it will be Putin's fifth term as president of Russia after being re-elected to one term in 2018, before passing a constitutional amendment in 2020, known as the "reset presidential term" (resetting the presidential term to zero), allowing Putin runs for president until 2036.
Putin seized power from Boris Yeltsin in a poor and crisis-plagued economy that either plummeted or slid slowly throughout the 1990s. This period was characterized by phenomena inconsistent with the "healthy rules" of the market economy, widespread commodity speculation and monopoly, wage arrears, rampant inflation, continued unexpected surges in the ruble (local currency) exchange rate to the country's detriment, in addition to There are huge budget deficits and national debts, wage payment defaults and non-payment of wages.
The list also includes managers of questionable integrity, institutions on the brink of bankruptcy and overwhelming gang power.
This was all in peacetime, when data and reports showed that the Soviet Union's economic growth during World War II was better than that of the 1990s, and despite having huge reserves of strategic wealth, especially oil and gas, the superpower was re-inventing itself in many areas. Back to the ranks of third world countries.
Added to this is the decline of Russia's major role on the international stage, internal unrest, rising separatist sentiments, or demands for greater sovereignty in many parts of the country, which at some stages manifested themselves in armed rebellions.
These data play a real role in assessing Putin's governance since 1999, and in many cases they form the basis of any methodology based on the first and last Soviet president Mikhail Gorba Comparative factors between Jov and the era of Boris Yeltsin, Russia’s first president after the collapse of the Soviet Union.

translation:
Fifth, hold high the banner of anti-hegemony and lead Russia in its efforts to maintain international strategic balance.

From the time when Russia suffered the bitter consequences of dealing with the United States during the Yeltsin period, to when he realized after being fooled and deceived by the United States in the early days of his administration, Putin personally felt that the United States' strategy towards Russia was completely to weaken and dismember Russia. From the Iraq War to NATO's bombing of Yugoslavia, I have witnessed the unilateral dominance of the United States in the international community, and gradually established the concept that the United States is "completely unreliable" and must be "resolutely resisted" and "establish a fair new international order."

For more than 20 years, Putin has repeatedly declared that "the 'Yanks' have humiliated us", "the existence of the United States is a tragedy for the people of the world", "the so-called unipolar world based on the hegemony of one or a few countries is Russia's "Unacceptable", "Russia is willing to cooperate with its allies and all relevant countries to deal with common challenges facing mankind." Putin keeps his word, and the relationship between Russia and the United States is gradually drifting away, even heading towards boycott and confrontation. The essence of Russia's special military action against Ukraine two years ago was Russia's military counterattack against the unilateral hegemony of the United States.

Many facts in the international community show that Putin has become a fighter on the front line against the United States and hegemony. Under his leadership, Russia has become an important force in maintaining international strategic balance and world stability.

title: В России завершились выборы президента. Как прошло голосование, что происходило на участках и на границе с Украиной?
translation:
The first three-day presidential election in the country's history has ended in Russia. Four candidates ran for the post of head of state. The process of expressing the will of citizens was accompanied by clashes with Ukrainian forces on the border in the Kursk and Belgorod regions, as well as incidents at polling stations in different cities. How the voting process took place and what is known about the results is in the Lenta.ru material.

The Russian presidential elections ended on March 17 at 21:00 Moscow time, when at 20:00 local time zone polling stations closed in the westernmost point of the country - the Kaliningrad region. Now the election commissions begin counting votes.

According to official information, the overall turnout in the Russian presidential elections, including remote electronic voting, was 77.44 percent, which was the highest figure in the history of modern Russia. title: 俄罗斯大选2024·议题｜参军、跳槽、养娃……“我们在同一条船上”
translation:
Some analysts believe that this is related to the increase in population mobility after the COVID-19 epidemic and the continued return of people who left Russia after the Russia-Ukraine conflict. On the other hand, it is also closely related to high inflation and increasingly higher benchmark interest rates.
According to data released by the Russian State Statistics Service in January this year, Russia’s inflation rate in 2023 will be 7.42%. In order to curb inflation, the Central Bank of Russia has raised its benchmark interest rate several times since July 2023. On February 16 this year, the Russian Central Bank announced that it would keep the benchmark interest rate unchanged at 16%. As home loan interest rates rise, more and more Russians are turning their attention to the rental market, further boosting demand for rental housing. With supply exceeding demand and rising prices, many landlords have chosen to raise rents.
This trend is still continuing. Taking the capital Moscow as an example, data provided by Yandex Rent shows that in January this year, the average rent of a one-bedroom apartment in Moscow rose to 55,000 rubles (approximately RMB 4,389), and the average rent of a two-bedroom apartment reached 80,000 rubles (approximately RMB 4,389). RMB 6384). According to data from the Moscow Statistics Bureau, from January to September 2023, the average salary in Moscow increased by 15.4% year-on-year to 78,600 rubles (approximately RMB 6,280).
Regarding the housing issue, Putin responded in his 2024 State of the Union address. In 2023, Russia will have more than 110 million square meters of new housing area. In the future, Russia will continue to increase investment and provide preferential mortgage loan policies to make housing affordable for ordinary families, especially to reduce the housing pressure on families with many children.
Before starting his own small family, Dmitry once shared a three-bedroom apartment with two of his friends in order to save rent. After having his own children, Dmitry took out a loan to buy a property of his own, relying on the above-average salary brought by his job as a programmer and the subsidies provided by "Mother Capital".
Now, Dmitry no longer has to worry about housing. For him, perhaps the biggest worry is the uncertainty of when the war will end. Although he lives near Moscow, far away from the front line, he has heard news more than once that a drone was shot down nearby. He had also felt fear when he heard that Prigozhin and Wagner's soldiers were marching towards Moscow.
Regarding politics, Dmitri did not like to discuss too much. He admitted that he was not a fan of Putin, but now he had no choice. At the same time, he also has no good opinion of Western countries that provide Ukraine with large amounts of weapons. The only thing Dmitry is sure of is that his country is fighting a war it cannot lose.
"I have a complicated attitude towards the war. We had reasons to start this war, but it is still very sad that all this happened... But I am convinced that we must win."
input:
Price increases.
Performance increase in various sectors and measures.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜普京获近九成选票，胜选后抨击美式民主
translation:
In the early morning of March 18, 2024 local time, in Moscow, Russia, Russian President Vladimir Putin delivered a speech at a press conference at the Moscow campaign headquarters.   Visual China Map

According to Xinhua News Agency, data released by the Russian Central Election Commission in the early morning of March 18, local time, showed that among the more than 95% of the votes counted in the Russian presidential election, the current President Vladimir Putin was significantly ahead of other candidates with more than 87% of the votes. In fact, has won this presidential election.
According to Global Network, Russian Satellite News Agency reported that Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters in the early morning of the 18th. In his speech, he thanked voters for their trust and support and stated that he would continue to promote national development during his new term.
Putin leads by a wide margin
Russia holds presidential elections from March 15 to 17. For the first time ever, voting took place over three days and featured online voting, which covered about a third of Russia's regions.
According to CCTV news, voting for the 2024 Russian presidential election ended at 21:00 local time in Moscow on the 17th (2:00 on the 18th Beijing time), and all polling stations across Russia have been closed.
According to the latest vote counting results posted on the video wall of the Russian Central Election Commission, 95.08% of the votes for the 2024 presidential election have been counted. Current Russian President Vladimir Putin (Vladimir Putin), who is running as an independent candidate, has Leading with 87.32% of the votes.
Nikolai Kharitonov, candidate of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, came in second with 4.28% of the vote, followed by Vladislav Davankov, candidate of the New People's Party of Russia, with 3.85% of the vote. The candidate of the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia, Leonid Slutsky, ranked fourth with 3.15% of the vote.
The Russian government stated that the turnout rate for the 2024 Russian presidential election was 74%, setting a record high. Putin's previous highest vote record was in the 2018 presidential election, when Putin won 76.7% of the vote, and the turnout rate that year was 67.5%.
According to the Russian presidential election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes in the election is elected president. The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the results of the presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within 3 days after the election results are confirmed.
Russian state television pointed out in the report that "this is an incredible show of support and unity around Vladimir Putin, and it is also a signal to Western countries."
Konstantin Kosachev, deputy speaker of the Russian Federation Council (the upper house of parliament), said that international observers invited by Russian parliamentarians to monitor the Russian presidential election raised no objections during the more than three days of voting.
Kosachev said on the social platform Telegram that the general consensus among observers is that the Russian presidential election meets the highest international standards; it is fair and honest.

Putin delivering a speech.
Putin thanking Russian voters in a speech.
Promotion of national development by Vladimir Putin.
Putin's vote share and turnout rate set new records in the 2024 Russian presidential election.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜选票上，除了普京还有谁？
translation:
Putin: Moving towards a fifth term, not participating in pre-election debates
Vladimir Putin was born on October 7, 1952 in Leningrad (now St. Petersburg). He served as the 5th (1999) and 9th (2008-2012) Prime Minister of Russia, and the 3rd and 4th (2000-2008), 6th and 7th (2012-2024) Prime Ministers of Russia. ) President (During 2012, Russia revised its constitution and extended the presidential term from 4 to 6 years).
Putin

According to the Kremlin website, Putin wanted to work in the Soviet intelligence service "long before he graduated from school." He went to a KGB recruitment center where he was advised to study for a law degree first. In 1970, Putin entered the Law Department of Leningrad State University (now St. Petersburg State University) and received an associate doctorate in economics in 1975.
After graduating from college, Putin began working in the KGB. In 1985, he was sent to work in the Democratic Republic of Germany. In 1989, Putin, a low-level KGB agent stationed in Dresden, was involved in the wave of drastic changes in Eastern Europe. Putin returned to China in 1990 and began his political career in Leningrad. He served as foreign affairs assistant to the president of Leningrad University, advisor to the mayor of St. Petersburg, and first deputy mayor of St. Petersburg.
Since 1996, Putin has held a number of senior positions in Moscow, including deputy director of the Russian Presidential Affairs Service, deputy director of the Russian Presidential Administration and director of the General Inspectorate, first deputy director of the Russian Presidential Administration, director of the Russian Federal Security Service, Russian Federal Security Service Conference secretary, etc. In 1999, he was appointed prime minister by then Russian President Yeltsin. On December 31, Yeltsin suddenly announced his resignation as president, and Putin was appointed as acting president. On March 26, 2000, Putin was elected President of Russia. Since then, Putin has served as President of Russia except for serving as Prime Minister from 2008 to 2012.
If Putin can win the general election in March 2024, it will be his fifth term as president of Russia.

title: 普京大胜,谁赞成,谁反对？
translation:
The current Russian presidential election was held from March 15th to 17th. According to the results of the first two days, more than 90% of the votes were counted, and Putin had won. Today, Russia's Central Election Commission officially announced that Putin won the current Russian presidential election and will start a new six-year term.
Before this election, the whole world basically predicted that Putin would win in the end. However, the West still laid out three "black Putin" points in advance.
First, the Western media searched intensively, hoping to find violent anti-Putin demonstrations during the election process, or riots that disrupted election stations.
Second, the Western media focuses on the total number of voters. Even if Putin wins, if the total number of voters is not as good as before, the West can boast that the "silent majority" is the real public opinion against it.
The third one is the support rate for Putin’s final victory. This year is the fifth presidential election that Putin has participated in. Each time the support rate is different. If the support rate drops this time, the West can also hype Putin's decline in control or the rise of people's anti-Putin desire.
As a result, Putin not only won the election, but I called him a great victory because when he won, he exposed the three major plots of the West.
In terms of "anti-Putin rallies and destruction of election stations", the West made plans in advance, abandoning Navalny, who was exiled in the Arctic and losing influence, and supported his "widow" in the hope of becoming a black widow to attack Putin.
The opposition led by Navariny indeed called on the Russian people hoarse on foreign social media to refuse to vote. Or vote no. As a result, very few people responded. Western media searched all over Russia and found only "anti-election news" about an old Russian man throwing paint at a polling station.
In addition, in this election, Putin's approval rate also broke previous election records, reaching an astonishing 87.3% when the total number of voters broke the historical record, exceeding 74%.
Putin's vote rate when he first ran for office was 53% in 2000, 71% in 2004, 63% in 2012, and 76% in 2018. In other words, Putin's approval rate this year is 10% higher than during his peak period in history.
The ultra-high turnout combined with the ultra-high support rate made it clear to the world that it was not Putin's personal wishes that drove the Russia-Ukraine conflict, but that NATO's eastward expansion trampled on the security concepts shared by all Russians. .
Faced with Putin's great victory, the attitudes of countries around the world are different. The subtext is that some people support it and some people oppose it.

The official voting for the eighth presidential election of the Russian Federation will be held from the 15th to the 17th. According to Russia's presidential election rules, the person who gets more than half of the votes can be elected president. If there are more than two presidential candidates and no candidate obtains more than half of the votes cast, the Central Election Commission will announce that the two leading candidates will advance to the second round of voting. In the second round of voting, the top vote-getter is elected.
The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the results of the presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within 3 days after the election results are confirmed.

title: 多名俄官员支持普京竞选连任，俄总统大选投票将首次持续三天
translation:
According to reports from Xinhua News Agency on December 8, citing TASS, Russia Today and other media, Russian President Vladimir Putin said that day that he would participate in the presidential election in 2024. Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, announced on the 8th that voting in the 2024 Russian presidential election will be held for three days, lasting from March 15th to 17th.
This will be Russia's first three-day presidential election vote. The multi-day voting method has previously been used during the coronavirus pandemic to prevent overcrowding of voters at polling stations. It is reported that the first application of this method was during the Russian constitutional referendum from June 25 to July 1, 2020.
In addition, voting in this presidential election will also be conducted using a combination of on-site voting and remote electronic voting. Voters can apply for remote electronic voting from January 29 to March 11, 2024. The official voting time is March 15 From 8:00 on Sunday to 20:00 on March 17. At present, the Russian Central Election Commission has not announced the regions where remote electronic voting can be used. Russia's Central Election Commission is expected to make a decision on December 12 on whether to hold voting in the four "new regions" of Donetsk, Luhansk, Zaporozhye and Kherson.
On December 8, Putin attended the "Heroes of the Motherland Day" celebration ceremony at the Kremlin. After the ceremony, Artyom Zoga, Chairman of the People's Committee of the "Donetsk People's Republic", said in a conversation with Putin that the entire Donbas region hopes that Putin will participate in the election.
He said to Putin: "You are our president, we are your team. We need you, Russia needs you." In response, Putin responded: "I had different ideas at different times, but now the time has come to do what must be done It’s time to make a decision. I will run for president of Russia.”
After Putin announced his participation in the 2024 election, many Russian officials expressed support.
Matviyenko, chairman of the Russian Federation Council (the upper house of parliament), said that Putin’s decision is a guarantee for Russia as a strong, secure and sovereign country.
Volodin, chairman of the Russian State Duma (lower house of parliament), said that Putin's decision to participate in the election is very important for Russia and the world. Putin's decision demonstrates his love for Russia and his desire to make Russia strong and prosperous. It also demonstrates his desire to protect Russia in the current difficult period full of challenges and threats.
Medvedev, deputy chairman of the Security Council of the Russian Federation, said that considering the current situation, Putin's decision is absolutely reasonable and correct, and Putin should continue to serve as president.
If the 71-year-old Putin can win the general election in March 2024 and be successfully re-elected, it will be his fifth term as President of Russia. Putin's current term as President of Russia will end on May 7, 2024. According to the Russian constitution, Putin can seek re-election for two terms until 2036 after this term ends.
Currently, among the five political parties in the Russian parliament, the United Russia Party and the "Just Russia-Patriots-For Truth" party have made it clear that they will support Putin's presidential bid. Zyuganov, Chairman of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, has previously stated that he will participate in the election, but the final decision will be made by the Central Committee of the Party. The Russian Liberal Democratic Party and the Newcomer Party are also expected to nominate presidential candidates from their respective parties.
Outside parliament, Yabolu party leader Yavlinsky said that if he could collect 100,000 signatures from supporters to qualify for the election, he would run for president. Independent candidates, including former Russian local TV reporter Yekaterina Duntsova who called for an end to "special military operations," need to convene an initiative group of at least 500 people and obtain more than 300,000 signatures from supporters. Only in order to be eligible to participate in the election.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜五个“首次”，这场选举有何特殊？
translation:
According to CCTV News, official voting for the Russian presidential election will be held from March 15 to 17. Four candidates, including current President Vladimir Putin, are running.
According to information released by the Russian Central Election Commission, the four final candidates confirmed in this election include: Putin, Slutsky (Russian Liberal Democratic Party), Kharitonov (Russian Federation Communist Party) and Davankov (Russian newcomer party).
The 2024 Russian election will be the country’s first presidential election after the adoption of a constitutional amendment in 2020, and it will also be Russia’s first wartime election. What are the key points of this election, and what are the special features worthy of attention compared with previous elections?
Who is eligible to run?
In January 2020, Russian President Vladimir Putin initiated the constitutional amendment process. The draft amendment to the Constitution of the Russian Federation was approved by the Russian State Duma and the Russian Federation Council in March, and then came into effect after a referendum in July of that year.
According to this constitutional amendment, the President of the Russian Federation is elected by the citizens of the Russian Federation on the basis of universal equality and direct suffrage by secret ballot for a term of 6 years. Citizens of the Russian Federation who are over 35 years old, have lived in the Russian Federation for at least 25 years, and do not have foreign citizenship or residence permit are eligible to run for President of the Russian Federation.
Furthermore, the same person may not serve as President of the Russian Federation for more than two consecutive terms. This provision has not changed, except that this limit does not include the number of terms in office that were and/or are currently serving as President of the Russian Federation at the time when the amendment comes into force. Current President Putin can still participate in the 2024 presidential election.
input:
Participation of current Russian President Vladimir Putin in a presidential election with three other candidates.
Putin's 2020 constitutional amendment process.
Russian constitutional referendum in 2020.

title: 俄罗斯大选：普京宣布压倒性胜利，赞俄罗斯民主优于很多西方国家 - BBC News 中文
translation:
As expected, Putin overwhelmingly won a fifth presidential term in the election, with the other three candidates acting as runners.
When election officials announced that Putin had won more than 87% of the vote, Putin pointed out that Russia's democracy is more transparent than many Western countries. The fact is that no credible opposition figure has been allowed to run.
After the sudden death of dissident leader Alexei Navalny last month, his supporters launched a symbolic protest called "Noon Against Putin", calling on Russian citizens to take to the streets of Moscow, St. Petersburg and other cities at noon. and gathered in front of Russian embassies and consulates abroad. However, this did not sway the election results.
Monitoring group OVD-Info said at least 80 Russian protesters were arrested for disrupting election order. Green dye was poured into ballot boxes and fireworks were set off inside polling stations on Friday.
Western countries have condemned the election as neither free nor fair.
Germany called it a "pseudo election" held under an authoritarian rule that relies on censorship, repression and violence. British Foreign Secretary David Cameron condemned "the illegal holding of elections on Ukrainian soil."
Ukrainian President Zelensky said that "the Russian dictator is simulating another kind of election."
In the words of Navalny ally Leonid Volkov, who was savagely beaten with a meat hammer while living in exile in Lithuania last week: "Of course, Putin's vote has nothing to do with reality."
Russians have three days to vote in this election, and in Russian-occupied Ukraine, residents have even longer to vote. This is to encourage residents to participate in voting.
An election commission official was reportedly killed in occupied Berdyansk on Sunday, and residents said pro-Russian figures, accompanied by armed soldiers, were visiting homes with ballot boxes.
On state television, which is carefully controlled by the Russian government, the election results were hailed as a victory, with official turnout reported as high as 74%.
One reporter said excitedly: "The support and solidarity for Putin has reached an incredible level, which is also a signal to Western countries."
President Putin kept a low profile when taking questions from reporters, but he did praise Russia's presidential campaign as being much more advanced than the United States, citing Russia's use of online voting, which officials said attracted 8 million voters.
Putin was also photographed voting online earlier. He said: "This is transparent and absolutely objective, unlike mail-in voting in the United States... you can buy a vote for $10."
Putin, 71, has ruled Russia since 2000 and is the longest-serving Kremlin leader since Soviet dictator Joseph Stalin, and is expected to remain in power until at least 2030.
Independent election watchdog Golos was not allowed to observe the vote, but there were reports of irregularities during the election and public sector employees being pressured to vote at polling stations or online.
President Putin praised opposition activists for encouraging more voters to go to the polls, but he condemned those who sabotaged ballots and said action would be taken against them.

translation:
On March 21, local time, the Russian Central Election Commission held a meeting to summarize the results of the 2024 presidential election. Data showed that 87,576,075 voters participated in the voting, with a turnout rate of 77.49%.
Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, officially announced that day that according to preliminary statistics of all votes, current Russian President Vladimir Putin won 87.28% of the votes and won the 2024 presidential election.
Data shows that a total of 76,277,708 voters voted for current President Putin. Kharitonov, the candidate of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, Davankov, the candidate of the New People's Party of Russia, and Slutsky, the candidate of the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia, received 4.31%, 3.85%, and 3.20% of the votes respectively.

Regarding the global response after the attack, Zhang Jiadong analyzed that from the perspective of counter-terrorism, Russia and the United States may cooperate, because terrorism is essentially a crime against humanity. title: 俄罗斯大选2024·布局｜冲突笼罩下的选战
translation:
"The question is to what extent this trend will continue over time," he said.
Independent analyst Alexandra Prokopenko, who once worked for the Russian Central Bank, also previously wrote in an article that war-related money has greatly reduced the number of poor people. The proportion of Russians living below the poverty line fell to 9.8% for the first time since 1992 (note, according to the latest data released by Rosstat in March, Russia's poverty level fell by 0.5%. It fell from 9.8% to 9.3% for the whole year . 800,000 people are no longer "officially poor").
"In 2024, this momentum is likely to continue - the government will have to pay 2-3 trillion rubles to the families of the dead and injured." Alexandra Prokopenko writes that due to labor shortages, companies must not Don’t pay the remaining people well or attract them from other departments. Wage growth is higher than the national average in regions such as Novosibirsk, Samara, Sverdlovsk, Nizhny Novgorod and Tula, where defense industry enterprises are concentrated.
Data obtained by Bloomberg from local recruitment service Superjob in January also showed that in Russia, professionals such as engineers, mechanics, machine operators, welders, drivers and couriers can now find jobs with salaries comparable to or higher than military positions. , because wages for such jobs have increased by 8-20% in the past year.
However, Anders Aslund, a well-known economist who has long tracked the Russian economy, published an article on the website of the liberal media "Moscow Times" warning that in terms of economic structure and major indicators, the Russian economy seems to be increasingly like the Soviet Union. "The unemployment rate is below 3%, but average wages in dollar terms have plummeted from $1,200 per month in 2013 to just under $600 per month currently."
In the spring of 2023, a series of protests took place in several regions of Russia, especially the Novosibirsk region and Altai Krai, against the increase in utility costs and the inability of local governments to improve utility networks. The anger in these protests is generally not directed at the federal government, but governors and regional government agencies face higher risks as most regions have increasingly limited budgets and growing priorities.
Denis Volkov of the Levada Center believes that economically disadvantaged groups are slightly more resilient to the situation - their demands are more modest and they respond more positively to government support measures. In contrast, economic sanctions from Western countries have mainly hit the wealthier and more Westernized areas of Russia's major cities.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·特写｜堡垒、新领土和“变得更像俄罗斯”的小村庄
translation:
"Karina previously told The Paper.
When the voting opened on March 15, Karina rushed to the polling station early to cast her vote. Like most Russians, Karina understands that the outcome of the election will come as no surprises. However, for her, the vote still has a special meaning.
"Donbas has confirmed its future with Russia," Karina said. "This is the most important thing."
On March 15, 2024 local time, people in Donetsk voted at the polling station in the Russian presidential election.

Since February 24, 2022, many people in Karina’s family have joined the militia. Her brother Sasha had already entered the military camp and became an officer of the First Army of Donetsk. This is a militia force composed mostly of locals. Its predecessor began fighting against the Ukrainian government forces as early as 2014 after the "Square Revolution" in Kiev. During the ten years of fighting, the two sides could be described as having a "blood feud." As the Russian-Ukrainian conflict broke out in an all-round way, the Russian army entered Donbass in large numbers, and the First Army was gradually formalized and integrated into the Russian army's command system.
Karina's husband and father have donned military uniforms and gone to the front lines to fight. My father, who is over 50 years old, was once a junior officer in the Soviet army, but he has been retired for nearly 30 years and has lost most of his military skills.
"I told Dad that you had fulfilled your military mission when you were young. But he said, how could I leave Sasha alone in the trenches. So he carried a packed backpack without asking me or my mother. , one person went to the recruitment point to report." Karina said.
In recent times, with the cooperation of other Russian military units, the First Donetsk Army has participated head-on in attacks on satellite towns in the western suburbs of Donetsk such as Malinka and Avdeyevka. After these towns were occupied, the line of fighting between the Russian and Ukrainian armies was pushed further west, and the artillery fire gradually moved away from the urban area of ​​Donetsk. For locals like Karina who self-identify as Russians, the smooth conduct of the election means the "hinterlandization" of Donetsk, where daily life has become safer.

title: Как проходили выборы Президента России в 2024 году
translation:
The Russian Presidential elections took place from March 15 to 17, 2024. Four candidates participated in them: self-nominated incumbent President Vladimir Putin, from the LDPR - Leonid Slutsky, from the Communist Party of the Russian Federation - Nikolai Kharitonov, from the New People - Vladislav Davankov.

According to the Central Election Commission, a total of 87.28 percent of voters, or 76,277,708 people, voted for Putin.In second place was Kharitonov with 4.31 percent of the votes, in third place was Davankov with 3.85 percent, and in fourth place was Slutsky with 3.2 percent.

The turnout was 77.49 percent of the total number of voters.

Polling stations were open to voters from 8:00 to 20:00 local time. It was also possible to vote online. This is the first presidential election in which such an opportunity has arisen. About 38 million voters from 29 regions were able to take part in online voting.

Abroad, it was possible to vote at 295 polling stations; they opened in 144 countries.Monitoring of the presidential elections in Russia was carried out by observers from the Interparliamentary Assembly (IPA) of the CIS from 22 countries. The group includes deputies and senators from Commonwealth countries, as well as experts from the International Institute for Monitoring Democracy Development from Moldova, Turkmenistan, Laos, Egypt, Vietnam, China, Iran, Cameroon, Cote d'Ivoire, Palestine, Syria, Sudan, Turkey, Croatia and Great Britain.
