title: Итоги выборов президента: Победа Путина, второе место КПРФ, рекордная явка
translation:
The most important indicator is voter turnout. It was 77.44%. Voter turnout was a record high in the history of Russian presidential elections.

In 1991 - when the only presidential elections of the RSFSR took place - 76.66% of voters came to the polling stations. In all subsequent years, turnout in presidential elections was always high (65% and above), but the 70% bar could not be overcome. In this sense, the current elections can be called historic. The desire of people to vote, as experts note, was influenced by the consolidation of society and the convenient format of the elections themselves - polling stations worked for three days, for the first time there was access to online (in 29 regions).


For the first time in the presidential elections, Russian citizens in 29 regions could vote online
Turnout was higher than the Russian average in new regions, whose residents were electing the President of Russia for the first time - in the DPR, LPR, Zaporozhye and Kherson regions, more than 80% of voters came to the polling stations.

The Chechen Republic, North Ossetia-Alania, Kabardino-Balkaria, Tyva, Kemerovo Region, and Yamalo-Nenets Autonomous Okrug passed the 90% turnout threshold.

The turnout for online voting is always higher than in-person voting, and it was also a record - 94% of those who applied. Almost 4.5 million voters checked electronic boxes on the federal platform. Moscow voted on a separate platform; almost 3.7 million electronic ballots were issued in the capital. The remote electronic voting infrastructure has generally coped with the load and hacker attacks, said Minister of Digital Development Maksut Shadayev.

There were violations and provocations (filling ballot boxes with green stuff and others) during the voting, but they were insignificant and were not capable of influencing the results of the expression of the will of citizens. This was stated by the Commissioner for Human Rights in the Russian Federation, Tatyana Moskalkova, and the head of the Human Rights Council under the President of the Russian Federation, Valery Fadeev. And the chairman of the Central Election Commission, Ella Pamfilova, announcing the first preliminary results of the elections, said this: “Together we are strong, we voted for Russia.”
input:

title: 俄罗斯总统大选：普京为何大费周章举行这次选举 - BBC News 中文
translation:
For government officials, the election will test their ability to marshal administrative resources to deliver a landslide victory for the president.
The Russian independent news website Meduza reported that the Kremlin hopes to achieve a turnout of at least 70%, with about 80% of the votes going to Putin. This would exceed his 76.7% vote share in 2018.
BBC research found that to achieve such an outcome, the authorities aimed to mobilize state sector employees, that is, those who work in central and local authorities and state-owned enterprises, to strongly encourage them to vote and support the sitting president.
There are approximately 112.3 million eligible voters in Russia.
This number includes Russian citizens living in the occupied territories of Ukraine, including parts of Crimea and the Donbas region illegally taken over by Russia in 2014, as well as other areas of eastern and southern Ukraine occupied since February 2022 .
An additional 1.9 million Russian citizens living abroad are eligible to vote, including 12,000 in neighboring Kazakhstan, where Russia leases the Baikonur space launch base.
Putin attended many events during the campaign, mainly meeting with students and workers in different regions of Russia.
While he avoided talking about "special military operations," Moscow's term for the invasion of Ukraine, the war is ubiquitous in Russian life: international sanctions, restricted travel options, reduced foreign goods, and conflicts with Europe and North America Feeling of isolation.
The war also claimed the lives of tens, if not hundreds, of thousands of Russian soldiers.

title: 普京顺利五连任是“假选举”？ 中国网民: 至少俄罗斯人能投票
translation:
According to a report by the Russian Satellite News Agency (Sputnik) on March 18, in the Russian general election, more than 4,300 Russian citizens living in China completed their voting at polling stations organized by six Russian overseas agencies, including Shanghai and Harbin. This triggered some Chinese Netizens left messages on Weibo and said sarcastically: "What kind of thing is it to set up a polling station in China to elect the president? Are you giving us eye drops?" Another netizen wrote with admiration: "Russians can also give Putin in China. Vote...they are happy."

During the Russian election, there were reports of voters destroying ballot boxes in many Russian cities to express protest against Putin's dictatorship and unlimited re-election.

In response to this, some Chinese netizens commented on Weibo and asked: "What does the ballot look like?" and "Ordinary people in Russia can still have access to the presidential election ballot box. I am envious." Some Chinese netizens seemed to be flattering Xi Jinping and joked: "Putin should learn from China's 'whole-process people's democracy', and no one would dare to find fault with him."

Xi Jinping published an article in Guangming Daily in March 2023, stating that the CCP’s whole-process people’s democracy is the “most authentic and effective” democracy, transcending capitalist party-based democracy and truly realizing that the people are the masters of the country.

While Putin won re-election through universal suffrage, Xi Jinping won a third term through constitutional amendments that were "unanimously approved" by 2,952 deputies at the National People's Congress in March 2023, breaking the practice of two ten-year terms for Chinese leaders. .

In this regard, Chen Pokong, a political commentator in New York, pointed out that the CCP’s “whole-process people’s democracy” is a “linguistic cosmetic technique” that packages autocracy as democracy. Various sarcastic messages from Chinese netizens show that in front of the relatively sober Chinese people, , this kind of political rhetoric has no persuasiveness.

title: 俄罗斯总统选举：普京、权力与抗议的可能性 | 政治 新闻 | 半岛电视台
translation:
A February survey conducted by VTsIOM, a Kremlin-controlled polling agency, showed that about 79% of Russians planned to vote for Putin.
Some ordinary Russians, adjusting to the wartime reality around them, awaited the vote with apathy and despair.
Mikhail, a freelance journalist from the suburbs of Moscow, told Al Jazeera, “Everyone seems to have gotten used to this situation, given up, and sometimes even started to try to benefit from it.” “Shock has been replaced by apathy and depression. "
It will be the first time in Russian history that voting will last three days instead of one. At the same time, voters in 29 regions can vote online for the first time.
About 112 million people in Russia aged 18 and over are eligible to vote.
People in the annexed Crimean peninsula and parts of occupied Ukraine will also take part in the vote, but Ukraine and its Western allies have condemned the move as illegal.
Millions of Russian nationals living abroad — from the Baikonur spaceport in southern Kazakhstan to the U.S. state of California — can also vote at local embassies, consulates or by mail.
The results of a poll released by the Kremlin-funded polling agency FOM on March 5 this year showed that at least 61% of Russians would "definitely" participate in the vote.
The poll showed another 16% were "likely" to vote, while only 9% would abstain.
Preliminary results are expected to be announced on March 19, with final results on March 29.
Russian official data shows that the official turnout is expected to be almost as high as in the 2018 vote, when nearly 68% of Russians voted.
In 2018, independent election monitors documented thousands of cases of electoral fraud, including ballot stuffing and "balloon voting," in which hundreds of voters were sent to multiple polling stations.
Some inspectors faced threats and were denied access to polling stations.
The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, an international election observer, said the vote was "overly controlled" and "lacked real competition." The report said authorities forced government employees, military personnel and law enforcement officers to vote for Putin.
Observers of Russian politics have little hope that the vote will be conducted in a free and fair manner.
Putin is running as an independent candidate because the ruling United Russia party is widely seen as corrupt and ineffective.
The late opposition leader Navalny called it "a party of liars and thieves."
Other candidates are seen as puppets – involved only to show how “popular” Putin is.
One of them was Nikolay Kharitonov from the Russian Communist Party. He was on the 2004 ballot and finished a distant second.

David Betz, professor of modern war studies at the Department of War Studies at King's College London, recently told The Paper, "Because of its strong economy, the Putin government is politically safe, and the Russian army is fighting effectively, and The casualty rate will not have a serious impact on society, and Russia's military industry is in full production of new weapons. "
András Tóth-Czifra also believes in his report that the stability of Russian domestic politics is guaranteed because a sufficient number of voters and elites have begun to believe that war is inevitable and victory is close; at the same time, the Russian government needs Maintaining the international community's perception that the Russians are prepared for a protracted war.
"Even with the great efforts of the Russian government, Russia's military production capabilities are about to reach their peak, and Russia does not have unlimited possibilities to increase production 10 or 20 times and continue on this path year after year." Oleksiy Melnyk, co-director of the Foreign Relations and International Security Project at the Ukrainian Economic and Political Research Center, disagrees. He recently told The Paper, “This is because if you use your budget or your industry capabilities to support the war effort, then you definitely have to reduce production on other civilian projects.”
On March 15, 2024 local time, in Moscow, Russia, voters cast their votes at a polling station during the 2024 Russian presidential election.

Feelings of different classes and the newly joined middle class group
At the broader social level, the mentality and emotions of the Russian people are also undergoing subtle changes. Denis Volkov, director of the Levada Center, a well-known Russian independent polling agency, wrote an article earlier this year that despite the impact of special military operations, Western sanctions and partial mobilization, according to poll results, two-thirds of Respondents considered 2023 to be relatively successful, with the highest value since 2000.
The survey revealed that "wage and pension rises" were among the top 10 events of the year for the second year running. The public's positive assessment of the economic situation is likely supported by the costs associated with "special military operations", since these costs are several times higher than the monthly income of most Russians. One interviewee, asked how her life had improved recently, said: "My son is at war and he sends money back."
Professor Herman, an expert on Russia, told The Paper that the Russian government has injected a large amount of money into the economy, which has promoted the increase in income in the military industry and some other industries, so the economic situation of many people is not that bad.

title: 普京在总统选举中胜选,赴竞选总部讲话谈新任期、俄乌局势
translation:
According to a CCTV International News report on the 18th, at 8pm local time on March 17th and 2am Beijing time today (March 18th), as the polling stations in Kaliningrad Oblast, the westernmost part of Russian territory, closed, the Russian President Election voting is over.

According to the latest news, among 80% of the votes that have been counted, current President Putin received 87.15% of the votes. According to Russian presidential election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes in the election is elected president.
Late at night on the 17th, Moscow time, Putin came to his campaign headquarters to express his gratitude to all Russian citizens who voted in the election, saying that he would continue to promote national development during his new term. Putin also answered questions from reporters on special military operations, the possibility of negotiations with Ukraine, relations with the United States, relations with NATO and other issues.

According to CCTV News, the Russian Central Election Commission stated that as of 18:00 on the 17th, 74.4% of voters across Russia had participated in the voting. In the 2018 Russian presidential election, 67.54% of voters participated in the voting, and Putin received 76.69% of the votes.
According to Russia's presidential election rules, the person who gets more than half of the votes can be elected president. If there are more than two presidential candidates and no candidate obtains more than half of the votes, the Central Election Commission will announce that the two leading candidates will advance to the second round of voting. In the second round of voting, the winner is elected.

title: 连任后一片喊打！普京透露与习的关系-万维视频-万维读者网（电脑版）
translation:
After being re-elected, there was a cry of beating! Putin reveals relationship with Xi
Russia's Central Election Commission stated that Russian President Vladimir Putin won re-election in an overwhelming victory with a record-breaking 76 million votes, accounting for 87% of the general election. This result seems to indicate that the people of Russia are united in supporting this leader who has been in power for a long time. people. In the evening, Putin delivered his victory speech and revealed that Sino-Russian relations will reach a higher level. Speaking of Chinese President Xi Jinping, Putin said, "I believe that this relationship will continue to be maintained. This is largely due to the close personal relationship between President Xi Jinping and I." However, the West claims that more than 87% of people supporting Putin's re-election are a hoax.
From China to Cuba to North Korea, Russian President Vladimir Putin’s allies have been quick to stress that they welcome his re-election. Russia's electoral commission called it a "record." Agence France-Presse counted who congratulated Putin on his election today, and the Chinese Communist Party bore the brunt. Chinese President Xi Jinping said in a congratulatory letter to his Russian counterpart on Monday that "your re-election proves the full support and great trust of the Russian people," China Central Television said.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Communist Party of China stated that it believed that the relationship between China and Russia "will continue to make progress" and that the two countries are "comprehensive strategic cooperative partners" and this year marks the 75th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between the two countries.
Iran's official IRNA news agency said Iranian President Ibrahim Raisi "sincerely congratulated Putin on his solid victory and re-election as president of the Russian Federation."
As of Sunday evening, the leaders of Venezuela, Nicaragua, Cuba and Bolivia had congratulated Putin. Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro also said nauseously: "My brother has won, which is a good sign for the world."
The news said that India also congratulated Putin on his victory and said it would continue to develop India-Russia relations. Some analysts pointed out that India wants to continue to play both sides between the West and Russia.
Ukrainian President Zelensky said on social networks that Putin is "hungry for power and is making every effort to achieve permanent rule."
Britain in London lamented the lack of "free and fair" elections in Russia, with British Foreign Secretary David Cameron denouncing Russia on X for "illegally organizing elections on Ukrainian soil that left voters with a lack of choice."
Norway condemned that "Russia's so-called elections are neither free nor fair." Norwegian Foreign Minister Espen Bart Eide also condemned that some of the voting took place in "regions of Ukraine illegally occupied by Russia," believing that "this is a serious violation." Acts of International Law”.
European foreign affairs chief Josep Borrell declared on Monday that Putin's re-election was based on "repression and intimidation" and "was not a free and fair vote."
input:
Putin delivering a speech.
Maintaining the relationship between China and Russia.
China congratulating Putin on his re-election.
The development of bilateral relations between China and Russia.
Russia organizing elections.
Russian illegal occupation of Ukrainian territories.
Putin's regime and re-election based on repression, intimidation, and censorship.
Intimidation during Russian election.

title: «Угроза для Европы и мира». Что пишут зарубежные СМИ о победе Путина на выборах
translation:
Western media call Vladimir Putin's re-election as president of Russia expected and are speculating about what his fifth term in this position could be like. Details are in the RTVI material.

Three days of voting in the presidential election have ended in Russia. According to preliminary results, which the Central Election Commission publishes in real time, current President Vladimir Putin wins 87.3% of the vote, which is a record figure.

Western media call the voting results expected and a foregone conclusion, and also discuss the significance of Putin’s fifth term for world politics. The past Russian elections are “even more of a sham” than the previous ones, since “most of Putin’s real rivals” are “in exile,” in custody or dead.

“Putin’s fifth term poses a threat to Europe and the world,” the editorial said. The publication believes that the only factor that could “prevent Putin’s fifth term from extending into his sixth” is the failure of the Russian military operation in Ukraine. To do this, the West needs to “more effectively enforce sanctions” and convince developing countries of the need to comply with them, the FT believes. “The biggest challenge is to restore Western defenses as a deterrent and provide Ukraine with all the necessary support,” the newspaper summarizes.
input:
Putin winning his fifth presidential term.
Preliminary rigged election results showing Vladimir Putin receiving approximately 87% of the vote.
Putin's reelection in a predetermined Russian presidential election.
Putin's extension of his rule over Russia through a rigged election.
Convincing others of a particular viewpoint or legitimacy.
